Birds like the skylark, turtle dove, and lapwing represent love and magic in stories and poems. Losing these birds is a loss for our culture.
Folklore, which includes stories and legends about birds, is very important. These stories connect us to the past in a way that scientific facts cannot. They help us feel emotions that are often hidden in our busy lives. Whether we watch birds on TV or in our gardens, the joy we feel cannot be fully explained by science. Birds engage us in ways that are hard to describe, and the stories we tell about them help us understand their significance. The wren in the greenhouse connects our present with a rich history, reminding us of the mystery and beauty of nature.

**Maps**
The purpose of a map is to show the relationships between different places and features on the earth. These relationships are based on distance and direction. In the past, people often measured distance in time, like saying "it takes so many hours to walk" or "a day's journey by river." This way of measuring helped people understand how easy it was to travel through different areas, rather than giving exact distances.
Direction is also important, but for most travelers, the main questions were "Where do I go from here?" and "How far away is it?" Because of this, written directions were often just as important as maps. Even today, some maps, like those for train systems, do not always show true directions. In the past, important landmarks along a route were marked by signs that varied in size to show their importance.
The way maps are made has changed a lot over time. Cartography, the study of making maps, has improved in how accurately it shows distance and direction. Other sciences have helped in this process. For example, instead of using shadows or stars to find direction, people started using compasses and tools to measure angles accurately.
As explorers learned more about the world, they tried to create better maps. Astronomers found out that the earth is not a perfect sphere, which helped improve large area maps. The needs of map users also changed. Soldiers, especially after the invention of cannons, needed accurate maps to understand the land better. This led to the creation of contour maps.
Other people, like archaeologists and historians, also needed maps for their work. Today, cartographers create maps for many different purposes, including geology and land use. The importance of maps in many sciences has led to a new interest in cartography.
It is important to understand that the development of maps has not always been smooth. There have been times when progress slowed down, and old ideas stayed alongside new ones. Cartographers have often had good ideas but had to wait for better tools to use them. Since it is easy to copy old maps, many map publishers have been slow to accept new ideas. Therefore, we should not always trust maps as the best evidence of current knowledge and techniques.
The many maps we have today are the result of a lot of human effort and thought. They are valuable records for studying human history. This is what makes the study of historical cartography interesting and important.

**Tim Rice**
I was taken into a young man's living room. It was a nice and calm place, very different from the messy rooms where the other family members were. Moving from the kitchen to his room felt like going from economy to business class. This room had the biggest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player I had come across, and it was surprising to see a teenager who had bought nice wine glasses, pictures, and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had a scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford, to study history, and he had nine months before starting school. During this time, he wanted to become a famous composer like Richard Rodgers.
I also had big dreams. I wanted to be a pop star for the usual reasons: women, money, and fame. But my dreams were not as important to me as Andrew's were to him. When Andrew suggested that I try to become a famous lyricist like Oscar Hammerstein, I was happy to give it a try. This was partly because, within ten minutes of meeting him, he played me three of his own songs on the piano. I could tell he was very talented. As he played more songs from the shows he had written at school, I remembered some of the best albums from my parents' collection.
He needed a new lyricist for his music. I didn’t have much to show him, except for my praise for his music and a single I had written with a pop group that had not done well. We said we would meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in pop music than in theatre, but on the bus back to my flat, I thought I had met someone special who would be very successful in musical theatre.
Even if we didn’t become famous composers, we could try to write songs for popular bands like the Beatles and Rolling Stones later. The Everly Brothers had just made a comeback and would need new songs. The next day, back at my office where I was training to be a lawyer, I felt less sure about my future in show business with Andrew. I would still look for ads in Melody Maker for groups needing a singer and write more simple songs. But it was likely that I would finish my exams and become a lawyer by the time I was twenty-five. My father thought I would stop enjoying pop music by the time I was twenty-one, which worried me. I felt I had only a few months left to enjoy it.
But I thought it would be fun to see Andrew again. We could go to a musical together and write lyrics for musicals instead of pop songs. Andrew was an interesting person who talked about good food and old buildings, and he supported Leyton Orient football team. I wasn’t sure about the musical idea he had been working on for a year, but in 1965, I often doubted things. His talent was clear, and he said he had many important contacts.
I went back to his living room. The idea was about Dr. Thomas Barnardo, a man from the 19th century who started orphanages. His story was important, but it didn’t excite me. The hero seemed too perfect, and the idea felt unoriginal, similar to the popular show, Oliver. However, Andrew was very confident about his music, and his excitement was contagious. I didn’t know much about musicals, but I thought there could be room for more than one musical.
I started working with a lot of enthusiasm, especially for the funny songs. Andrew explained the story, played me the tunes, and often gave me the titles, which were probably thought up by his friend from school. I even skipped a day at the law office, pretending to be sick, to write my first lyrics for the musical. I didn’t know it then, but I was changing my career.

**Language**  
You and I are part of a species that can communicate in a special way. Language is very important in our lives, and it is hard to imagine life without it. When people are together, they usually talk to each other. If there is no one to talk to, people often talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I think of language as an 'instinct.' This means that people know how to talk, just like spiders know how to make webs. Spiders do not need to learn how to spin webs; they just do it naturally.
**Climate and Weather**  
Climate and weather, which are created by the air around us, greatly affect animals and plants. Climate can change how landscapes look. For example, warm and wet weather all year allows tropical jungles to grow, which have many different types of plants and animals. In contrast, cold and windy areas have fewer living things. Daily weather changes, which together create the climate, happen because of large air movements. The air moves because the Earth spins, and the sun also causes a lot of this movement.
**Coffee**  
As a barista, my job included serving drinks, but I was also responsible for making coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on how good its coffee is. I spent several days learning how to make coffee and how to clean the espresso machine. I learned the important steps to make a great cappuccino. By the end of the first week, I realized that making good coffee was harder than it seemed, and I thought I might have to go back to cleaning ashtrays. Fortunately, my boss was patient. He told me, "Making coffee is both an art and a science, and you need time to learn it."

**Art on TV**
Why does television often have problems with programs about visual arts? Painting and sculpture are good subjects for the camera because it can show the whole artwork and then zoom in to see the details. However, there are not many TV series that show the joy and complexity of looking at art. A good example of this is Robert Hughes's series called *American Visions*. Hughes is a trusted critic with a strong personality, and he had almost eight hours to introduce British viewers to American art, which is often ignored in British galleries. I thought the series would focus on great artworks, but instead, it looked at how American history and culture are shown in its art and buildings.
**Dealing in Metals**
For 20 years, I worked as an international metals dealer and became known as a speculator. The metals market is not as regulated as other markets. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, it is possible to make a lot of money. Taking risks is part of this industry. This adventurous culture fits well with a free-market global economy. However, the free-trade economists who believed that the market would keep the prices of rare metals high have found that the opposite is true. More minerals are being mined, and the cost of raw materials is going down. When considering inflation, the prices of most metals are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to investigate claims against a large company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.
**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**
Abaco and its nearby cays are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas, which stretch from Florida to Cuba. Each island has its own character and something special to offer. To get around the islands and cays of Abaco, you need a boat. If a boat is not included with your room, don’t worry. There are many ferries and water taxis available. Build Your Own Bamboo Bike in the UK**
You can build your own bamboo bike at the Bamboo Bike Club, the first workshop of its kind in the UK. This course is run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan. When you join, you get a custom bike frame designed by a computer and a fun weekend of bike-building.
It is Saturday morning in Hackney Wick, east London. The Bamboo Bike Club is busy with people working on their bikes. Bamboo is becoming popular for making bikes. Companies like Calfee Design from California and Bamboo Bikes from Yorkshire have been making bamboo bikes since 1894. However, many cyclists find these bikes too expensive. A ready-made bamboo frame can cost around $2,995 or £1,868.
James and Ian wanted to create a bamboo bike business that everyone could afford. They spent years working in a shed in Brecon, Wales, to develop their idea. They realized they did not just want to sell bike frames; they wanted to help people enjoy making something special and sustainable. So, the Bamboo Bike Club was born. James works on wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer, but they run the club in their free time.
The club offers monthly courses where you can build your own bike. The price includes a custom bike frame and a fun weekend. On the first day, James and Ian teach you how to choose strong bamboo and how to make strong joints. You start by building the front triangle of the bike with thick bamboo, and then you add thinner pieces for the seat and chain. Some metal parts are used for the handlebars and wheels because they need to be strong.
James and Ian help everyone during the building process. They check every cut and joint to make sure everything is correct. If someone has trouble, they step in to help. Many people in the course are engineers, but Ian says that everyone makes mistakes sometimes. If you mess up, you can just try again with a new piece of bamboo.
On Sunday, you spend time building the lugs, which are the parts that connect the bike frame. You wrap the joints with hemp and glue them to make them strong. After adding a waterproof coating, your bike is ready for wheels, brakes, and other personal touches. James and Ian say their bamboo bikes are just as strong as metal bikes. Ian has been riding his bike for over a year, and James has tested his bike off-road for three months without breaking it.
The bamboo bikes may not look as polished as metal bikes, but they are unique. James and Ian believe that the special look of bamboo is part of the charm. I think bamboo bikes are great for relaxed rides rather than racing. I choose a 'Classic English' frame for a comfortable ride. When I try James's bike, it feels light and smooth, even on bumpy roads.
James says that the best part of the workshop is when you ride the bike. They are light and fun to ride. The price for building your own bamboo bike is less than £500.

**Self-help Books**  
Diane Reverend was an editor at Random House in New York when she first saw a book by a new pop psychologist, Dr. John Gray. She thought the title was great and believed it would be a bestseller, and she was right. Dr. Gray became very successful, and Diane started her own company. Dr. Gray's book helps people understand each other better in relationships and is very popular in the self-help industry. This industry tries to meet people's desires for improvement in their lives. However, it also creates many new desires and supports the publishing industry in New York. In Britain, people are seeing that many self-help books can be strange and exaggerated, but there are even worse ones. For every self-help book published, many others are rejected because they are too similar or too specific. This is a good thing. Editors are now looking for the next big hit, and they care more about how marketable a book is than its writing style. Diane says that if someone has a catchy title, it makes it easier to attract readers.
**Autobiographies**  
When someone writes an autobiography, there is an unspoken agreement that they will tell the truth. However, this agreement is often not fully kept. Writers may leave out things they feel are too shameful or not important. Sometimes, they might invent stories that express the truth better than just sticking to the facts. They might even call their book an autobiography just to make readers believe it is true, even if it is mostly fiction. This can happen without any bad intentions.
**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**  
People who study detective stories say that this genre reflects the problems of society in the late 1800s and early 1900s. A detective story often shows a crime that represents human desires like greed or lust. Solving the crime helps bring society back to order. In Hammett's stories, society is shown to be corrupt. The detective and the criminal are two sides of the same person. The detective understands the criminal, and they have a strange connection. The detective is seen as too honest by criminals and too shady by the law. His job is complicated because he feels connected to both sides.
**Science Writing**  
Stephen Jay Gould is a well-known science writer. I met him at the Grand Hotel while he was promoting his new book. We both felt out of place there. Gould said he could not write well in such a fancy place because understanding the culture is important for a writer. Science is its own world, and only scientists can explain it well. If you don’t know the community and its rules, you will struggle. Gould believes that writers should not talk down to their readers. He says, "You can make the language easier, but you must keep the ideas strong. If readers feel you are treating them like they are less smart, they will not enjoy your writing."

**Air-conditioning**
At Cannons Gym, a popular place for City of London workers during lunch, it is very cold inside. To handle the high temperatures this summer, the gym has used a lot of air-conditioning. Sometimes, when it is quiet, the gym feels like the Arctic. This shows how we often misuse air-conditioning today. It is now a common part of our work and leisure, showing how we try to control the climate. However, many buildings with air-conditioning could use other ways to stay cool. They could use natural light and fresh air, and have thicker walls that keep heat out during the day and let it go at night. These ideas may seem simple, but they can really help and would reduce the need for air-conditioning.
**Sundials**
It is interesting that as we start a new millennium, more people are interested in sundials. Sundials are tools that tell time by using the sun's position. A hundred years ago, they were very important for keeping time. But as clocks and watches became better, sundials were mostly seen as garden decorations. Now, they are being taken seriously again. David Harber, who makes sundials, thinks people like them because they connect us to the planets. He says there is a special moment when a sundial starts to work. They are calm and beautiful objects that remind us of our place in the universe.
**Paint Your Own China**
My idea of china-painting came from a visit to an arts and crafts show a long time ago. There, I saw serious-looking older women showing how to paint flowers on a teacup with careful brushstrokes. It was amazing to watch because each stroke created a perfect petal or leaf. Their hands were steady, and the paint never smudged. I thought these women must have practiced for many years or had a special talent. Because of this, I wondered what kind of people would join a china-painting class. Would beginners be good at it? When I attended a class, I found out that the atmosphere was friendly and fun. The students were there to enjoy themselves, and even the teacher did not want to paint like the women I had seen before.

The Wrong Country**
Uncle chose a package holiday for Keith and Dawne at a good price. They had a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice, in a hotel called Pensione Concordia. When they went to the travel agency to book the trip, the clerk told them that the other people in their group were students from the south coast who were learning Italian. 
But something went wrong. They ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, in Switzerland. At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their tickets and said everything was fine. An hour later, they were surprised to hear older people on the plane speaking with accents from the North of England. Keith thought there might have been a cancellation or that the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks and then heard a woman say, "The coach will take us on," when they landed. 
There was no mention of an overnight stop in the brochure, but when the coach arrived, Keith realized that they were staying there for the night. It was close to midnight, and they were tired, so they did not question the beds they were offered. The next morning, they found out they were supposed to stay there for their whole holiday, and they became worried. 
The receptionist smiled and said, "We have the lake and the water birds. You can take a boat to Interlaken." Keith calmly told him, "There has been a mistake. We were meant to be in Venice, at the Pensione Concordia." The receptionist did not know that hotel. 
Dawne added, "The man who booked our trip was bald, with glasses and a moustache." She gave the name of the travel agency in London. A woman named Mrs. Franks, who was with a man with a bad leg, came over and smiled at Keith. She said, "I noticed you at Gatwick." 
Keith explained, "We got into the wrong group. We reported to the Your-Kind-of-Holiday girl." Dawne said, "We should have known when they weren't from Dover." Keith wished she would let him talk. 
Mrs. Franks explained that there are many different holidays that the travel agency offers. She said, "All tickets look similar, with yellow and red labels. If you followed others with the same label, you might think you could end up anywhere!" 
Keith insisted, "We are not meant to be in Switzerland." Mrs. Franks then walked away, leaving them confused. The receptionist was gone, and they could hear typing. 
Dawne whispered, "She seems nice." But Keith was not listening. He thought about everything that had happened: giving the tickets, waiting, and getting on the plane. An old man interrupted his thoughts, saying, "Nice to have some young people here." 
Keith and Dawne walked outside the hotel. They did not say anything to each other about the strange situation. This was their first holiday since their honeymoon, and they had ended up on a trip with older people when they wanted to escape from that. Uncle had said so himself when they tried to convince him to join them.

'HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON'**
American business leaders are looking to the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a good example of management. Eluned Price reports.
Most people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and what he did. However, America has only recently discovered him. The Wall Street Journal called Shackleton "an Antarctic explorer whose achievements went mostly unnoticed for most of the 20th century," which is not entirely true. Now, Americans are showing great interest in him. Many books and stories about Shackleton's journey on the Endurance are being published quickly. The American Museum of Natural History is planning a big exhibition, and a film about Shackleton's life is being made.
Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They talk about his actions with great respect and find lessons in his leadership and communication skills. They even refer to each other as "speaking Shackleton." Shackleton, known for his determination and resourcefulness, has become a model for modern management consultants.
Jim MacGregor, a managing partner at Abernathy MacGregor Frank in New York, has looked up to Shackleton for many years. His firm focuses on communication during mergers, acquisitions, and crises. For example, they help companies when there are serious problems, like when a factory explodes or when many employees must be let go. MacGregor believes that even if a company handles a crisis well, it can still cause problems if it communicates poorly. He says, "Shackleton is a model for management because of his qualities as a leader and communicator. He had strong values and was at his best when he and his team had a lot to lose, like their lives."
One of Shackleton's most interesting decisions was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole. This choice showed his credibility for the next journey: the safety of his men was the most important thing. In a crisis, people want to know who is in charge. While many managers today avoid responsibility, Shackleton was willing to take charge.
His 1914 expedition became legendary. His ship, the Endurance, was trapped in ice for nine months and eventually sank. When the ship went down, Shackleton told his men, "We should all reach safety if you do your best and trust me." From the diaries kept during the journey, it is clear that Shackleton was always in control. MacGregor says, "Shackleton thought everything through, planned for every situation, kept his men informed, and asked for their opinions. He was flexible and ready to change plans if needed."
Shackleton believed that an explorer needs optimism, strength, and patience. MacGregor adds, "One of the hardest things to do in tough times is to wait, especially in America, where people want quick solutions. If you invest money and make a mistake, it is better to wait and get your money back than to sell and lose a lot. Also, don't be afraid to change your plans if they are not working."
Shackleton led by example. On the way back from the Endurance, he saw Hurley, the expedition photographer, without gloves. He gave Hurley his own gloves, saying he would throw them overboard if Hurley did not wear them. Someone else remembered Shackleton doing something similar with a biscuit when they were very hungry on a previous expedition. He said he would leave the biscuit in the snow because it was so valuable.
As Caroline Alexander, the author of "Endurance," says: "People are increasingly interested in heroic efforts. Shackleton shows that there is not much heroism today. He stands out as a true example of the ideals we long for now."

'Finding Food in Madagascar'**
In the forests of Madagascar, there is a special animal called the aye-aye. This animal has a way of finding food that is similar to how a woodpecker does. Both the aye-aye and the woodpecker look for insects inside wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes in the wood and its long tongue to get the insects out. The aye-aye, however, uses its sharp front teeth to chew into the wood and its long third finger to reach inside and get the insects.
Scientists have studied the aye-aye's feeding habits for many years. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University has been watching two male aye-ayes named Nosferatu and Poe, and a female named Samantha with her baby, Annabelle. He wanted to find out how they find insects hidden in the wood. 
Dr. Erickson first checked if the aye-ayes could see signs of insects, like holes in the wood where insects might have laid eggs. He gave them logs with holes he had made. Some holes had mealworms inside, while others were empty. The aye-ayes went straight to the logs with food, showing that they did not need to see the holes to find the mealworms. 
Dr. Erickson thought the aye-ayes might be using their sense of smell or hearing to find the insects. However, he found that they could still find food even when the smell was blocked or when the mealworms were dead and silent. This made him wonder how they were able to locate the insects.
He discovered that the aye-ayes could feel the empty spaces inside the wood. When looking for food, an aye-aye taps the wood with its long middle finger and listens carefully with its big ears. Dr. Erickson believes that the aye-aye is using a method called echo-location, where it listens for sounds that tell it there is a hollow space in the wood. It can also hear insects moving when they are disturbed.
Some scientists think that the aye-aye might take the place of woodpeckers in Madagascar, but there are also birds like the Sickle-billed and Nuthatch Vangas that look for insects in wood. So, the woodpecker role may not be empty. 
The aye-aye is not only like a woodpecker but also like a bat that uses echo-location. It also behaves like a squirrel. Its front teeth keep growing, just like a squirrel's, and it has been seen in the wild chewing through nuts and using its long finger to get the nut meat out.

'Ordinary People, Ordinary Lives'**
Many of us have pictures of our grandparents, but how many of us really know what their lives were like when they were young? Sometimes, we can learn a little from old diaries or family stories, but these are often not enough. And what will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write down our stories, but we don’t always do it. We might leave videos instead of photos, but videos can only show a part of our lives.
Hannah Renier has found a solution. She writes autobiographies for other people, creating a book of at least 20,000 words, with pictures if needed. She focuses on the lives of ordinary people, not famous ones. The idea started when she spoke to her family and realized that many stories from the past were being forgotten. 
"When I began, I didn’t take it as seriously as I do now," she says. "I have met many people who have interesting stories to tell. They often say they are doing it for their children or for future generations, but they enjoy the process too."
People feel safe to share their stories with her because she keeps everything private. A 62-year-old man who shared his life story said, "I felt free to be honest. I talked about painful things, like my divorce." He wanted to share his experiences with his family, but he hasn’t let his children read it yet because he thinks some details might hurt them. He believes it might be better for them to read it after he is gone.
Hannah has noticed that many people are influenced by their parents throughout their lives. "It’s surprising how much childhood experiences affect adults," she says. "People often repeat the same patterns in their lives, whether they marry someone their parents liked or choose a partner to rebel against their parents."
Many people still feel regret about things that happened long ago. Even after many years, they may still struggle with issues from their childhood. They often try to impress parents who were never satisfied, and some even want to express their dislike for their parents.
Hannah listens carefully and does not push people to share more than they want. "I’m not here to judge or be nosy," she explains. "Sometimes people tell me something and then worry if it should be included. I usually keep it in, but they can change it later if they want."
Her work is not about showing off interesting lives. She believes that as life moves quickly, we are losing touch with our past. Writing these stories helps people connect with their roots and understand their family history. 
Each book is created from about 30 hours of recorded interviews, which Hannah uses to write the life story. She organizes the information and writes it well. The final book looks professional and costs nearly £3,000, with extra copies available for £25 each. Although she gets about 10 inquiries a week, the price stops many people from using her service. 
"I thought more people would want this service," she says. "But most of my clients are from wealthy backgrounds, who are used to preserving their family history."

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**  
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has a large collection of casts of Greek and Roman sculptures, with over six hundred pieces. It is important to know that none of the sculptures are real; they are all replicas made from the original sculptures, mostly created in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is in a specially built gallery with great natural light. The plaster casts have many benefits: sculptures that were originally displayed together but are now in different museums can be seen together here. You can see almost all the famous Greek and Roman sculptures in just one afternoon.
**B. Cambridge Darkroom**  
Cambridge Darkroom is a photography center with community darkrooms and a gallery that shows different photography exhibitions. We offer courses and workshops for people of all ages and skill levels, including a popular Beginner's Course, a shorter Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. We have a membership program that allows members to use our darkrooms. We also support young photographers (ages 12 to 16) to improve their skills through our Young Members scheme, led by our resident photographer. We sell photography books and magazines and have a full range of photography materials.
**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**  
The Sedgwick Museum has a wonderful collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all over the world and from different geological ages. It also has Britain's oldest complete geological collection, created by Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728). This collection has nearly 10,000 rare specimens stored in their original cabinets from the early 18th century. Adam Sedgwick was a Professor of Geology and helped to grow the collection, making it a great museum. The collection is organized by geological age, showing how life on Earth has changed over time. The new Whewell Gallery displays beautiful minerals and gems, with labels that explain what they are and how they are used today.
**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**  
The collection has over 400,000 air photographs taken by university staff over the last 45 years. The university has its own aircraft at Cambridge Airport and takes photographs all over Great Britain. These photographs are interesting because they show the landscape year by year, including the natural environment and how humans have changed it from prehistoric times to now. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the library staff can help with questions. The photographs cannot be borrowed, but you can usually buy copies, which take about a month to prepare.
**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**  
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is the second oldest and longest-running center of its kind in the world. It is a unique tourist attraction where you can enjoy making wall hangings by rubbing over one of more than a hundred different brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. The center creates resin copies, called facsimiles, to protect the original plates while allowing everyone to enjoy brass rubbing. These brass plates were used as memorials and spread from Germany to medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many beautiful brass plates were destroyed during various revolutions, but most of the remaining ones are in Britain, and you can see the largest variety at the Cambridge Centre.

**From Here to Fatherhood**
**A. The Theatre Director**  
I have had a strange personal life, but I have enjoyed 35 years with small children. I loved feeding my baby this morning, and that is what being a father means to me. I feel very lucky with my children. We all enjoy the same things: opera, theatre, books, and music. This has created a strong bond between us, especially now that they are mostly grown up and I feel more like a friend than a father. I do not believe in hitting children. I have slapped my kids when I was angry, but I do not think it is right. I may not have been the most attentive father, but I have always tried to be there for them. I wait for them to call me instead of chasing them for contact, as I do not want to make them feel guilty.
**B. The Advertising Executive**  
I was young when my children were born, around 25 years old. I found the responsibilities hard at first, but they also kept me feeling young. As my kids became teenagers, they introduced me to music, youth culture, and fashion, which helped me in my job. I missed some important events like their first concerts and sports days because I was busy starting my business. I feel sad about that, but now I can take them on holidays to nice places like the south of France. They get along well with my friends and come to parties and work events without feeling nervous. I think it helps that my job is seen as interesting.
**C. The Politician**  
My first child was born just before I was elected to the Greater London Council, and I had more children soon after. My wife and I promised to spend time with them, but my political work has made it hard to find time. I only accept weekend meetings and events where my kids can come with me. This way, they can see what I do when I am not with them, and they do not feel like I am disappearing. I have noticed that more politicians are bringing their kids to work, which shows we are becoming more aware of including our children in our lives.
**D. The Writer**  
My first marriage ended when my daughters, Kate and Bonnie, were young, so I had to think more about being a father. I worked hard to stay close to my children. My ex-wife and I even tried living next to each other for a while, so they could visit easily, but I think it confused them. Kate has said I was always there for her, but I am not sure I was a good father. I was around a lot, but I treated my kids like adults too soon. Kate recently said we were too relaxed with rules. I wish I had set more structure for them. I still worry about my older daughters just as much as my youngest. In that way, your children always stay with you.
**E. The TV Presenter**  
I was ready to have kids when I turned 30. I met my wife, and we had a nice home, so we thought, "Why not have a child instead of just buying new things?" Having my daughter, Betty, has helped me understand who I am. It feels special to have a child, but it also makes you just one of many parents. Sometimes I feel frustrated, but just one smile from her makes everything better. A baby's smile is the best way to feel happy again.

**THEATRE**
**A. Tamburlaine the Great**  
Marlowe's play about a powerful warrior can feel very long, but Terry Hands' production makes it exciting. He has cut parts of the text and created a fast-paced show. Antony Sher plays the main character and gives a great performance, doing stunts and keeping the audience's attention with his intense desire for power.  
*Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*
**B. Women Laughing**  
This play by the late Michael Wall is now in London after being shown in Manchester. The first act creates a tense feeling as two married couples talk on a sunny lawn. In the second act, the story changes and shows the serious effects of illness. Wall was a talented writer who died too young at 44.  
*Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)*
**C. Amphibians**  
Billy Roche is a new Irish playwright who has added to English theatre. His plays are set in Wexford, and this one looks at the problems in the fishing industry with strong characters, deep emotions, and some funny moments. The play can feel a bit aimless at times, but it builds to an exciting ending.  
*Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*
**D. Murder by Misadventure**  
This is a traditional thriller about "the perfect murder." Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play two crime writers who want to kill each other. Although the story is familiar, the surprises are clever.  
*Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)*
**E. The Alchemist**  
Young director Sam Mendes brings out the best in Jonson's comedy about 17th-century tricksters. After a successful run in Stratford, the show is now on the Barbican's main stage, with Jonathan Hyde, David Bradley, and Joanne Pearce giving great performances as the three con-artists.  
*Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*
**F. The Madras House**  
Peter James' production of Harley Granville Barker's comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society is now in London after being successful at the Edinburgh Festival. The staging is stylish, the acting is excellent, and the play is a classic that deserves more attention.  
*Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)*
**G. Dreams from a Summer House**  
This new musical by Alan Ayckbourn tells a version of Beauty and the Beast set in a London suburb. It has a beautiful score by John Pattison and celebrates romantic love, making it a feel-good show.  
*Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)*
**H. The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's comedy is not very good, but it has great performances from Ron Cook as Dr. Caius and Anton Lesser as the jealous husband, Ford. Other actors seem a bit embarrassed.  
*Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*
**I. The Voysey Inheritance**  
This is another important revival of Granville Barker's work, now touring. It tells the story of a respectable lawyer who leaves a corrupt legacy to his son, resulting in a wonderful play.  
*Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)*

**Hide and Seek**  
Yvonne Coppard  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game where they watch a strange bookshop. Emma sees that one of the few customers is her Uncle Jim. He tricks her and tries to turn her against her friends. When Emma's life is in danger, the story becomes very serious. She is trapped in the cellar of an old house. This book shows family life, childhood friendships, and warns that adults are not always safe. It is an important and interesting read.
**Backtrack**  
Peter Hunt  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, work together when they find out that their family members were involved in a train accident in 1915, where eight people died. Different viewpoints and documents like maps and personal stories help the reader understand what happened. This is a clever and complex novel that needs careful reading.
**Pigeon Summer**  
Ann Turnbull  
Mary Dyer does not fit in with her family or the male-dominated culture. She loves her father's racing pigeons and takes care of them when he goes away for work, even though her mother is upset. Set in 1930, this story has a good message: "There are different kinds of cleverness." Thoughtful readers will enjoy it.
**Yaxley's Cat**  
Robert Westall  
In this chilling story, a mature woman named Rose rents a cottage to escape her busy life and her husband. She brings her two children with her. A fierce cat and strange items in the cottage reveal why the last tenant, Sepp Yaxley, disappeared. However, the locals do not welcome them, and their lives are in danger. By the end, the violence is controlled, but Rose is still troubled by her son’s behavior. It is very gripping.
**Someone's Mother is Missing**  
Harry Mazer  
Sam is a chubby and talkative boy who admires his cool cousin, Lisa, who comes from a rich family. When Lisa's life falls apart, Sam helps her find balance, and they both learn the importance of family. The story moves slowly in some parts, but it has gentle humor and shows the growing friendship between the two teenagers. It can be interesting for both boys and girls.
**Stanley's Aquarium**  
Barry Faville  
Barry Faville writes with confidence and humor, describing his New Zealand setting and creating a likable main character, Robbie. Robbie takes a job gardening for an old man named Stanley. At first, Stanley is interesting, but later he becomes unpleasant. When Robbie discovers what is in Stanley's aquarium and what he plans to do, the story takes a thrilling turn while still exploring character and relationships. It is unusual and compelling.
**Dodger**  
Libby Gleeson  
This is a sad story about Mick, who has troubled relationships and a difficult school life. The story is told through flashbacks, letters from a teacher, and Mick's own notes. Mick learns to deal with the negative views of others and his own low self-esteem through a school play and the help of a caring teacher. It is highly recommended, even though it is a painful read, especially at the end.

'Science and Weightlessness'**
Journalist Tom Mumford joins students who are testing their ideas in weightlessness. The aircraft looked normal from the outside. The pilot told the 13 students from Europe and America that it was built in 1964 and was a Boeing KC-135 refuelling tanker, based on the Boeing 707. But inside, it was very different. The inside was a long white tunnel with few windows and bright lights on the padded walls. Most of the seats were removed, except for a few at the back where the nervous students sat.
For a year, these students had competed to join this flight, which was offered by the European Space Agency. They had to suggest creative experiments to do in weightlessness. The best ideas won a place on this special flight, which was like a thrilling roller-coaster ride. For the next two hours, the Boeing would fly up and down, creating moments of weightlessness. 
When the pilot cut the engines at 3,000 meters, the aircraft would go higher for a moment before falling back down. During the few seconds of weightlessness, the students would feel like they were closer to the moon than to the Earth. The flight started smoothly, but soon the pilot put the plane into a steep climb for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, and we felt the pressure in our heads. Then, the engines stopped, and we experienced weightlessness almost immediately. 
For 20 seconds, we floated in silence. The floor felt like a trampoline, and just one step could send us flying to the ceiling. We floated around, and directions like left or right didn’t make sense anymore. After ten seconds of falling, the pilot pulled the plane up. Gravity returned, but it was not as sudden as before, and some students landed hard.
After the first curve, some students felt sick thinking about the 29 more to come. The flight included thirty curves, giving the students ten minutes of 'space time' for their experiments. The Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats always land on their feet. They released a device to test this, and one student managed to turn it over using a remote control. 
Another team from Germany looked at how metal joints are affected by weightlessness, which could help build future space stations. A group from Utah State University tried to create solar sails from thin liquid films that harden in sunlight. They believe that if they succeed, satellites could use solar sails like yachts use wind.
After two hours of flying, the students felt excited rather than sick. One student said, "It was an unforgettable experience. I wanted to be an astronaut before, but now I want it even more."

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**  
**JONATHON PORRITT TALKS TO DANNY DANZIGER**
Jonathon Porritt is the author of *Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology*. 
I had a strange time in my life when I didn’t have any summers. I went to New Zealand every summer, which is actually winter there. So, I had nine winters in a row, which was great because I like winter. My parents had the idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, “If you can plant trees on it, then you can have it.” The idea was that we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which is nice because my father grew up there. They found a piece of land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land was not very good, but it was good for planting trees. I have always loved land. I spent a year in Australia working on farms, so the idea of planting trees excited me. I think my family became more interested as we went along. 
I started planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, we had planted the whole 70 acres. In New Zealand in 1968, it rained a lot during that winter. It is funny to think of it as a happy time because it rained almost every day we were planting. I don’t think I have ever been so wet and cold for such a long time. Every morning was a challenge: getting ready to plant again. I would come out of the Land Rover warm and dry, but then the rain would start, and I would feel cold and wet. 
In that first year, I had a helper who was an experienced tree-planter, which was very helpful because I had never planted trees seriously before. You wear a planting bag around your neck and fill it with as many trees as you can. When the bag is full, it is heavy, but it gets easier when it is lighter. The hardest part was getting the lines straight for planting. You decide how far apart to plant the trees and then use three poles to make a straight line. Once you are in line, you plant all the way down and then come back. 
I enjoy hard work, and it made me fit. After a while, you can plant trees almost automatically. You get used to a rhythm and use the least number of movements to dig the hole. This rhythm is important in many farming jobs. You learn to take the tree out of the bag, dig a hole, put it in the ground, stamp it down, and move on. 
Mentally, it was interesting. My mind started to think about many things, including nature and our place in it. These thoughts have influenced my life since then. I have been back to New Zealand four times and watched the trees grow, which is very satisfying because I planted them. I always worry when I read news about strong winds or droughts in New Zealand. Such news makes me feel anxious. However, everything worked out well, and those trees are now 20 years old and healthy. 
I should add that I took a break from teaching and went back in 1984 for three months by myself. I wrote my first book there, *Seeing Green*. There is a simple cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, a table, and a chair. In the mornings, I wrote; in the afternoons, I pruned the trees; and in the evenings, I did research. My connection to that area is still very strong. It is the place I feel most connected to in terms of the bond between people and the earth.

'CARING FOR BADGER CUBS'**
"What now?" was my first thought when one of my helpers brought a cardboard box to me. My husband Derek and I have run an open farm in Somerset for six years, where we take care of orphaned animals. But the noise from the box—a mix of a cackle and a bark—was strange to me. I looked inside and saw three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their soft coats were like velvet, and their milky eyes looked up at me from their black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most badger cubs are born between January and March and live underground. If they lose their mother, they often die from hunger. 
These three cubs were found by builders who accidentally disturbed their home while working. Their mother was dead, but the cubs were still alive. I could see they were healthy but cold and whimpering. After removing fleas from them, I took them into the kitchen to warm them by the stove. There were two females named Primrose and Bluebell, and a male named Willow. At first, I fed them with a syringe, but I had to wipe them with a warm cloth first to make them feel like their mother was licking them. This helped them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, I fed them every four hours. After a week, they learned to drink from a bottle and started to move around, although a bit unsteady. They were happy together with a heated pad to keep them warm.
Three weeks later, I noticed that Willow seemed tired, but he was still eating. This was a warning sign. I should have acted quickly, but I didn’t realize how serious it was. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet said he died from a lung infection. When feeding animals with a bottle, it is important not to let them drink too fast, or the liquid can go into their lungs. In Willow's case, this caused an infection that was hard to treat because he was so small. I felt sad about losing him, but I continued to care for the other two cubs.
Then, a local farmer came to see me. He had found another male cub, abandoned by its mother. He knew she would not return, and the cub was cold and hungry. I named him Willow II. He was about two weeks younger than the females. Feeding him was very difficult. I had to keep moving the bottle and squeezing it to get him to drink. After ten minutes, he would finally latch on as if he hadn’t eaten all day. By the end of April, the females were eating creamed rice and anything else I offered. Willow II was happy to stop using the bottle, but he had trouble eating without making a mess. Eventually, I gave him a sausage, which he slowly learned to eat.
At nearly five months old, they were all eating cereals for breakfast, meat and vegetables for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds in the evening. Badgers usually eat 60% earthworms, plus beetles, baby rabbits, mice, and plants. My badgers were better off than others that year because it was very hot, and finding food was hard.
By August, my badgers started to be active at night. We often walked through the orchard, and they would chase each other and play. I learned to avoid their playful nips, but Derek sometimes got caught and ended up with bruises. During these walks, I saw other badgers in our field. They were looking for food because their own areas were disturbed. We were warned that they might come into our badger pen and harm the cubs, so we put metal over the gate to keep them out.
The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and many people wanted to help build a home for them on our farm. With advice from others, we designed a new home for the badgers. Our son Daniel drew the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels and a special gate. It had three rooms, one larger than the others, with a glass side so people could see inside. As we built it, the badgers explored the new home before going on their walks. Soon, they were more interested in the tunnels than in walking.
The building cost more than we expected, but a local bus company helped pay for it, and local businesses donated materials. Everyone wanted to see the badgers have a home. One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle. Half an hour later, I checked on them and saw three badgers curled up and sleeping.
Now, I don’t walk with them as often because they don’t wake up until midnight. We see Primrose only sometimes because she has joined another sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to say hello before running off into the night. This is their home now, and they have made it their own.

In Search of True North - The Man Behind Halley's Comet**
Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow the journey of Sir Edmund Halley, who studied compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports.
Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, one of his important achievements was to study the "variations of the compass" during his sea voyages on the warship Paramore. These variations are now called "declination," which is the angle between magnetic north and true north. Sailors needed to know this to correct their compasses and navigate the oceans accurately.
Halley was one of only two men in England at that time who were paid to do scientific research. He set out for the Cape Verde Islands to study declination in the North and South Atlantic, but his first trip ended early because of problems with the crew. He tried again and traveled to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. From this journey, Halley published a map in 1701 showing the compass variations in the Western and Southern Oceans. This map helped sailors for over a hundred years until changes in the Earth's magnetic field made it less accurate.
Dr. Clark wants to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's journey by retracing the route of the Paramore. He needs to raise £70,000 before he can start, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first expedition across Antarctica, is helping him.
Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while he was at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about Halley's life. "Halley had an amazing life," Dr. Clark says. "He was a respected scientist and led many expeditions. He was not only an astronomer but also studied geophysics. While he was Astronomer Royal, he mapped the stars and worked on other projects."
During this time, Halley created a diving bell and helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book, Principia Mathematica, which is important in physics. Dr. Clark believes that retracing Halley's journey will give him the recognition he deserves. His expedition, called "In the Wake of the Paramore," will also have scientific value. They will take measurements like Halley did, but with better tools. These measurements are important because the Earth's magnetic field is always changing.
Dr. Clark explains, "We usually measure the size of the magnetic field, but not its direction. To measure direction, we need to know true north." On this expedition, they will use satellites to find true north. The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments for the trip. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements, and Dr. Clark hopes his data will help fill in any gaps in the satellite's coverage of the Atlantic Ocean.
Halley's journey was significant because it was the first scientific expedition at sea, and he was the first civilian to be appointed as a naval captain for this purpose. 
Does Dr. Clark have what it takes to succeed in his journey? He has spent two years in Antarctica and worked in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey. He has also sailed the 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with different crews.
Does he share Halley's passion? "I am ready to give up eight months of my life for this, so some might say I'm obsessed. But I wouldn’t want to sail across the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his interesting life have given me a real sense of purpose."

**POWER DRESSING**
Every summer, the peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tail feathers to the hens. This behavior makes us think about a question that Charles Darwin wondered about: how can birds have such fancy features in a world where survival is tough? How do they manage to do this?
Zoologist Marion Petrie and her team from the Open University are studying the peacocks at Whipsnade to find answers, more than 100 years after Darwin's death. Darwin believed that living things change over time through evolution, not by special creation. He thought that the strongest and best-adapted individuals survive and have babies. However, he also thought that being the "fittest" usually means being tough or smart. In contrast, the peacock's tail seems to be a burden rather than an advantage. So, Darwin suggested another idea called "sexual selection," which means that females choose males based on their beauty.
Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different view. He believed that if peahens liked the males with the most beautiful tails, it must mean those males had some other important quality that helped them survive. So, the tail was not just for show; it was a sign of something valuable.
Today, scientists still debate this topic. Studying peafowl behavior is not easy, but the 200 birds at Whipsnade, which live like wild birds but are used to people, provide a good chance for research. Marion Petrie and her team have two main questions: Do peahens really prefer the males with the most beautiful tails? And do these males have other advantages, or is it just about looks?
The adult male peacocks show off in groups, and the hens compare them. Long observations and photographs suggest that the hens do prefer the males with the most eye spots on their tails. The more eye spots a tail has, the more mates the male attracts. However, it is still unclear if these attractive males are better in other ways.
William Hamilton from Oxford University has a theory that showy male birds are usually free from parasites, and their beautiful feathers show that they are healthy. There is some evidence for this in other bird species. However, Dr. Petrie and her team have not yet been able to check for parasites in the Whipsnade peacocks.
This year, Dr. Petrie is comparing the young of attractive males with those of less attractive males. Do the offspring of the attractive males grow faster? Are they healthier? If they are, it would support Wallace's idea that females choose males for practical reasons.
There is also an interesting idea from mathematician and biologist R A Fisher. He suggested that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, her sons will inherit that tail, and her daughters will prefer long tails. This could lead to a situation where males with the longest tails have the most mates, and the preference for long tails continues to grow. Modern computer models show that this could explain how peacocks developed their impressive tails. Interestingly, this would also support Darwin's idea that females might eventually choose males just for their beauty.

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**
Tom Cunliffe believes that the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He showed this with his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of beautiful yachts with new technology. Most of these boats come from a big change in boat design that happened 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat is quietly resting in a tidal creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but when you see it, you might think it is 100 years old. You might also think that I am a romantic person. Maybe I am, but I’m not sure.
My boat uses the best parts of old boat design, but modern technology has made it easier to build. However, even though technology is important in boat design, it often keeps sailors away from the real challenges of life at sea. These challenges are often what sailors want to experience when they go to sea. I don’t think sailors should go back to suffering through every difficulty. I believe it is important for my boats to have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable places to sleep. But why go sailing if every sail works by itself? Dealing with sails that flap in the wind is part of being a sailor.
Also, why should we change the steering position from a safe place at the back of the boat to a less safe spot in the middle? This change makes the inside of the boat feel like a big house, with a bed bigger than the one at home. For me, a boat should be a boat, not a house on the water.
When I bought my first boat, Hirta, to sail around Britain for a TV race, the previous owner said it had all the comforts but no luxury. During my time with Hirta, I learned how true this was. She had heavy sails, no running water, no electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics for navigation. Yet, she was the easiest boat I have ever sailed.
However, classic boats like Hirta need a lot of care. When I hurt my back, I realized I could not keep her anymore. I looked for a younger boat but could not find one, so I decided to build a new boat from scratch. The Westerman has never let me down. Although the designer, Nigel Irens, and his assistant, Ed Burnett, use computer programs, Irens first drew this boat on a paper napkin and then moved his ideas to the computer. After creating a model, we worked together to improve the design. The final version was perfect.
The completed boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of her first six races. She looks timeless, moves beautifully in the sea, and has a peaceful atmosphere inside, much of it made from reclaimed pitch pine. This is because she was designed only as a sailing boat, without thinking about furniture. This is the best way to design a boat. In her calmness, she shows that you don’t need to follow trends to be happy, and sometimes it is good to learn from the past. Made from wood treated with special glue, she does not take in water. So, she has the advantages of a fiberglass boat but looks, feels, and sails like a real boat.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**
Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are becoming very popular. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.
**A. HENLOW GRANGE**  
I was happy to go to Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the big 18th-century house was very comfortable, and I felt calm right away. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I started to join classes like yoga and body conditioning. The instructors were very skilled. I was surprised at how flexible I became during the week. They offer many treatments, including aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The facial treatment, which lasts an hour, made me feel like a new person. The staff were very friendly and professional. The atmosphere was full of energy and enthusiasm. Henlow is planning to make some big changes this year, including a new swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds. If you want to relax, you can read a magazine or take a peaceful walk in the garden. During my stay, I felt happier and had a better appetite. I left feeling wonderful and full of energy. I would love to visit again. This is a perfect place for busy women. Save Room 5 for me!  
*Marcella D'Argy Smith*
**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**  
The calm and relaxing feeling of this stately home was clear as soon as I walked into the reception area. The Hall has a beautifully decorated library, a lovely conservatory, and lots of space, so you can be alone if you want. When you arrive, everyone gets a medical check-up, which includes checking your weight and blood pressure. They called us patients, which felt strange because I am healthy. However, I was impressed that they quickly helped me with a shoulder problem found during the check-up. Each patient follows a specific diet. I lost weight without starving, but I was still hungry and got a headache on the second day. My daily menu included grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and a mix of fruit, yogurt, and hot broth for dinner. If you are not on a diet, you can eat in the main dining hall, where the food is tasty. You can have a massage or water therapy every other day. All extra treatments are reasonably priced.  
*Liz Gregory*
**C. CAREYS MANOR**  
Careys is not a health farm, but it is a lovely old manor with cozy log fires and a big lounge. If you are counting calories, you might want to skip the gourmet food. The French chef makes rich sauces and delicious desserts. Luckily, the hotel has a gym and a soft-water pool, so I could exercise after enjoying the food. There is also a spa bath, steam room, sauna, and treatment rooms. A big attraction is the sports injury clinic. I got advice on an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist suggested good posture, exercises, and massage. Careys is comfortable and luxurious, but also relaxed. If you want to explore, there is beautiful countryside around.  
*Beverly D'Silva*
**D. CLIVEDEN**  
Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, a swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. There are beautiful walks and gardens in the 376-acre estate. Waldo's is a famous restaurant with amazing dishes. It took me a long time to read the dinner menu because there were so many choices. The meal was fantastic, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice cream. I went to bed very happy! The next morning, I spent some time in the gym to burn off some calories before my next meal. In the Pavilion, I enjoyed a facial and an aromatherapy massage. I thought about the other journalists who would write about fitness and beauty treatments. Cliveden has everything you need if you want to stay fit before enjoying a meal at Waldo's.  
*Kay Letch*
**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**  
The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It is the best because it is the most delicious I have ever had. It is the worst because it has 360 calories, which is a lot if you want to lose weight. You have been warned! The second best thing is the wonderful aromatherapy massage. I chose relaxing oils and fell asleep twice during the massage. I had the best sleep in years. The place is modern and well-organized, with great facilities and comfortable rooms. There are many therapists and beauty rooms, so it is easy to book appointments. They offer many treatments, from manicures to deep-cleansing facials. The guests are a mix of people, including football teams, mothers and daughters, friends, and singles. I would love to take a break here every month.  
*Eve Cameron*

**NATURAL TALENTS**
In the seven million years since humans separated from chimpanzees, we have not changed much. Genetically, we are still more than 98% similar to chimps. This means that the differences between humans and animals are very recent. Our ability to create art and other things we think are unique to humans comes from just a small part of our genes. 
Recent studies show that many traits once thought to be only human are also found in animals. For example, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools. Chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as weapons, while sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys also have a simple form of language, with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. This means that there are not many clear differences between humans and animals, except for art.
If human art comes from a special genetic ability, it is strange that our ancestors did not create art for almost seven million years. The earliest forms of art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but these materials do not last long. We only have clear evidence of human art from about 35,000 years ago, with famous cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.
If we believe that our recent creativity makes us different, we need to think about how our art is different from animal art. Three main differences are often mentioned: human art is not useful, it is made for enjoyment, and it is learned rather than instinctive.
First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means that human art does not help us survive or pass on our genes, unlike many animal behaviors. While some human art communicates ideas, this is not the same as passing on genes. For example, birds sing to defend their territory or attract a mate, which helps them pass on their genes. So, by this idea, human art does seem different.
The second idea is that human art is made for enjoyment. We cannot ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mainly sing during the breeding season, so they might not be singing just for fun. Again, this makes human art seem unique.
The third idea is that human art is learned, not instinctive. Each human group has its own art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo are different from those in Paris. People can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some birds are born knowing how to sing their species' songs, even if they have never heard them before.
Human art changes quickly. For example, people can easily tell that a painting from the 20th century is different from the famous Mona Lisa. Art experts can often tell when a painting was made and who made it. However, two chimpanzees named Congo and Betsy created paintings that could confuse even experts. Congo made up to 33 paintings in one day and was upset when his pencil was taken away. They had an art show in London in 1957, and many of their paintings sold, which is something many human artists cannot do.
These chimpanzee paintings make the differences between human art and animal behavior less clear. Like human art, the chimpanzee paintings were not made for practical reasons; they were created for the enjoyment of the painter. Some might argue that human art is different because it is meant to communicate with others, while the chimpanzees did not care about sharing their art. However, some famous human art was also made for personal satisfaction, not for communication.

An Amazing Adventure**
The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on Earth. It is also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell his story. There are not many big adventures left and not many heroes. In the past, children's stories were about brave explorers with sunburnt skin and narrow eyes from looking far into the distance. Today, we do not see such people in stories or in real life. Or so I thought until I met Charles Blackmore.
Blackmore's big adventure was leading a group across the Taklamakan Desert. Its name means "once entered, you never come out," but local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of that amazing journey while sitting in his family home. The team he led had four Britons (one was a doctor), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have put everyone in danger and made the trip very difficult.
This mixed group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of the world's toughest desert, and Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating story about their journey. At that time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to find something new in his life, and to learn more about himself. "I always thought I would spend my whole life in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but suddenly I wanted to see who I really was outside of that. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried that I wouldn't come back because nobody had ever done that route before; we went into it without knowing what would happen. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was very good to us."
Anyone reading his amazing story will be surprised by the word "good." The team faced many hardships: sickness, extreme temperatures, severe thirst, and losing part of their water supply. "But," Blackmore explains, "when we were at our limit and the camels had not had water for seven days, we found some. We did not experience the desert's famous sandstorms. And we never felt the freezing cold that could have stopped us. That does not mean we did not face challenges all the time. The fine sand got into everything, especially our blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and for the heavy camels, which often fell over onto us."
"What pushed me on more than anything was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time did not allow for one. No aircraft ever flew over us. Once we got into the sandhills, we were completely alone. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very scared about my physical ability to do it. I remember the first day — we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that it was hard to breathe. I thought, 'We have to do it now!' At that moment, I was very scared."
If it was like that at the beginning, how did they feel at the end? "After walking for 1,000 kilometers, you are not going to give up. You have gone through so much; you have come so far. We were very thin but also very strong despite being tired. My body was fit, and my legs were strong. I could walk over anything."
In the middle of the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon, and thinking about his family. How did he feel about what they must have gone through? "Inside me, there is someone trying to find peace. When I have doubts about myself now, I think back to the image of the desert and remember that we managed to do that together. I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I have done. But when I think about my life, I think of my family and the happiness we share. Compared to that, the desert does not measure up."
Has Charles Blackmore found peace? "I long for the challenge — for the open spaces — the excitement of it all. We were lifted by our sense of purpose. Now, I find it hard to be part of the sameness of modern life."

Life was getting too busy for Susan Harr, so she decided to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us useful devices that make life easier and give us more free time. However, Susan feels that we have become too dependent on technology. 
She had a bad experience with her broken word processor, which cost her a lot of money to fix. This made her think that gadgets are often not worth the trouble. She started to let some of her household gadgets break down without replacing them. This made her question what "free time" really means. Does it just mean we have more time to buy and use more gadgets? 
When her broken gadget started making strange noises, she decided to leave it outside. Now, she enjoys taking her time with her sewing. She feels free from noisy machines and can carry her sewing supplies anywhere. 
There are some gadgets she still finds useful, like her washing machine. But she also found joy in giving up some devices. For example, she returned her rented color TV and went back to a small black-and-white one. This change helped her family spend more time walking their dog, reading, talking, and enjoying hobbies. 
Susan used to think she needed her sewing machine, but now it is just a table for plants. Since she cannot afford a new one, she has started sewing by hand. She realized that doing things by hand is not boring; it can be enjoyable. She can listen to the radio or talk with family while sewing. 
Sewing by hand gives her a nice feeling, especially when she sits by the fire with a cup of tea. She used to think that sewing by hand was hard work, but now she finds it relaxing and satisfying. She enjoys watching her work become better and faster. 
Now, she feels less rushed and has more control over her time. She even enjoys washing the dishes while daydreaming. Because of this, she is starting to think about what gadgets she really needs in her home. Do they really need a freezer, a microwave, or an electric lawnmower? She wonders if they could save money by not using electric lights!

Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who makes beautiful furniture. Joanna Watt meets him in his workshop, which is under a railway arch in East London. When I arrive, he shakes my hand quickly and says, "Well, fire away then!" He seems busy, and his workshop is full of furniture pieces and wooden planks in many colors.
Hurst has been a cabinet-maker for ten years and has a good reputation. He always has many orders, even though he does not advertise himself. People know that if they want a good cupboard, table, or bookcase, Hurst is the right person to contact. 
It is not hard to find a furniture-maker, but it is harder to find one who makes high-quality furniture with simple designs. Hurst says, "There are few real cabinet-makers now. Many people just call themselves furniture-makers." He is often disappointed by the quality of modern furniture. He does not like cheap, mass-produced items and believes that wanting perfection is important for his success.
Hurst is confident in his skills. He says, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." He learned his craft by asking questions and practicing. Most of his work comes from private clients, and some come back to him for more furniture. He enjoys making furniture for their whole house, but he finds it frustrating when clients do not know what they want.
Hurst is also kind and praises others when they deserve it. He says, "There are people far better than me." He believes that some craftsmen try to be artists and take too long to make one piece. He does not like degree shows where students show their work but focus too much on fashion. He thinks furniture should be useful, not just a statement.
Even though Hurst is confident, he is not pretentious. As I leave, he says, "After all, I am only making furniture," showing that he is humble about his work.

**Three Theories About Sleep**
People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This shows that sleep is very important. However, scientists do not fully agree on why we need to sleep. There are three main theories.
The first theory says that sleep is important for our bodies. It suggests that while we sleep, our bodies repair themselves and get ready for the next day.
The second theory focuses on learning. It says that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day. Without sleep, we might not be able to learn well.
The third theory talks about energy. It claims that we need to sleep to recharge our energy, so we can feel good and be active the next day.

**ECCENTRICS**
