I work in a team with three senior designers, a partner, and a junior designer. My job is mostly about production, with some design work. I get a brief from the client about what they want. I spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After that, I present my ideas to the client. If they like my ideas, we work on budgets and I hire photographers and illustrators. I also work with printers to make sure everything is done on time. I spend a lot of time managing people and need to communicate well. I often have to work on several projects at once, which can be very stressful. I have lunch at 1 pm for an hour, and we usually go to a pub. If the client likes my designs, it feels great, but it’s disappointing if they don’t. I usually get home by 7:30 pm, but sometimes it’s much later. I find it hard to relax after a busy day."
**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  
**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I usually wake up at 7 am, but on some days, I have to get up between 4:30 am and 5 am for long flights. At 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Since chauffeuring is a sitting job, I have to be careful about my diet and exercise. I usually have a big breakfast and snacks during the day. People often ask me for restaurant or shop recommendations, so I need to know the area well. Most jobs are pre-booked, which helps me plan my routes. Not all passengers are polite; some can be rude. But most are nice, and I have good relationships with my regular clients. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, so I have to be careful not to get too tired. I try to go to bed by 11 pm."
**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  
**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up at about 7 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and go to my first job. My assistant and I mostly take care of gardens we designed. We do some commercial work, but most is in private gardens. We spend about an hour and a half at each place. At around 11 am, we get hungry and go to a café for breakfast. In summer, I might work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. I have an office at home, so when I get back, I check messages and return calls. If someone wants a new garden, I usually meet them in the evening. We like to use old materials to make gardens look historic. Sometimes, clients have strange ideas, but it’s very satisfying to see a garden we created bloom. I find it hard to relax in the evenings because I can hear the phone ring. I sleep well because my job is very physical, and I am always tired at the end of the day."
**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  
**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the site by 8:30 am. I am an assistant engineer, and I help build bridges and a wall to keep cars safe. I check that the workers are following the plan and safety rules. I also help solve problems. The workers start at 6 am, so my first job is to find out what happened since I left the day before. I usually have paperwork to look at or questions to answer. I have lunch for about half an hour between 2 pm and 2:30 pm, but I often eat while I work. The workers have set meal times, so I check things while they eat. Because I check their work, we need to have a good relationship. I see the main engineer once a day, but if something important happens, I act quickly. I usually leave the site at about 6 pm and I am always on call."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**
**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7:30 am. I manage programs for our credit card users. My job includes starting and managing the Membership Rewards program in Europe. I keep in touch with current card users, find new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then check my emails. I work with marketing staff and advertising agencies to plan our advertising strategy. I have many meetings during the day, but I keep my door open for anyone who has questions. I travel to different markets in Europe once or twice a week. When I am in London, I leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.
**B. Record Company Executive**  
I arrive at work by 10:00 am and check the mail, which includes demo tapes, letters from producers, and concert information. The phone starts ringing around 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers. I have meetings throughout the day to discuss projects for artists. When I listen to demo tapes, I know that these are very important to the artists, so I try to give helpful feedback. Once I sign a band, we start working on their first album, choosing songs and a producer. I also manage budgets and spending. I usually leave work by 7:00 pm and often go to concerts in the evening, sometimes seeing up to five new bands. I often don’t get home until 1:00 am, when I listen to music to relax.
**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I check the mail and my schedule for the day. I enjoy showing customers around the showroom and selling furniture. We sell antiques that cost between £1,000 and £6,000. I spend time working with restorers and other specialists to fix the items we buy. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while drinking coffee to stay updated on the business. I do the accounts once a month and tax returns every three months. I go home at 5:30 pm, and it usually takes me about an hour to relax.
**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work on a set schedule. When I have an early shift, I leave home at 6:00 am. I start my shift at 7:00 am, taking over from the night shift. I work at different control positions in the tower, usually for about an hour and a half at a time. My team controls aircraft movements, and we handle about 1,000 movements a day in winter. Night shifts are quieter, and I can read about new air traffic rules. This job is stressful, and I find it hard to relax after work. I hope to become a watch manager and then a general manager of the airport.
**E. Shop Manager**  
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. I start by getting the electronic sales system ready. I make sure someone is watching the cash register and help coordinate breaks for staff. I spend the morning helping customers find and order books. I enjoy serving customers, but it can be challenging when they expect me to gather many books quickly. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm, publishers’ representatives visit, and I discuss new book titles with them. I need to ensure new titles arrive on time. My early shift ends at 5:45 pm. On two days a week, I work late and close the shop.
**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving by 8:45 am. I contact freelance reporters to find out what is happening in my area. I assess financial risks for companies working abroad, trying to warn clients about possible problems. I provide three services: an online news preview, a security forecast, and a travel information guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss the stories I will follow. I have deadlines for my reports, so I need to work quickly. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events. I leave work around 6:00 pm, but I often find it hard to relax and stay awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: Take Control at Work**
A. **What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A good leader inspires others and helps them change for the better. Leadership is not about being tall or very smart. Pat Dixon, who wrote the book *Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace*, says that leadership is about "making things happen through people who are as enthusiastic and interested as you are." Enthusiasm is very important. A good leader should be able to speak clearly and confidently. Dixon says, "It's having the confidence to say 'I believe' instead of 'I think.'"
B. John van Maurik, who teaches a Leadership in Management course, says, "Most people have more potential for leadership than they know." To become a leader, you need to recognize your talents, develop them, and use them. In a way, we are all born leaders; we just need the right environment to grow. While it is easy to see leadership in famous people like Emmeline Pankhurst, Mahatma Gandhi, or Richard Branson, it can be harder to see it in our own jobs. However, leadership is very important for good management.
C. Think about the best and worst boss you have had. They might have been good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these goals? The best leader motivated you and supported you. The worst leader made you feel unimportant and kept information from you. When things went wrong, they blamed you. The first boss led well; the second one managed badly.
D. Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within set rules. Leaders create new opportunities. Micheal Shea, who wrote *Leadership Rules*, says, "A good manager can keep a company running smoothly, but a good leader can change a discouraged organization, whether it is a company, a sports team, or a country."
E. Whether you are the boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some lessons to learn:  
- Leadership works best when you choose to do it. Find out what you are passionate about. When you feel inspired to lead, use that energy and take action.  
- Start thinking of yourself as a leader. Your ability to lead is an important part of you. Recognize it.  
- Working together is good, but sometimes strong leadership is needed. Try different styles. If you usually ask others for their opinions, try taking the lead instead. See how this changes the results.  
- Set goals and try to achieve them. Look at your job and see where being a leader can help you do better and advance in your career.
F.  
- Leadership does not just happen. It develops when you take the lead, take risks, and learn from mistakes. Learn to delegate tasks, motivate others, organize, and give praise.  
- Don’t think that your way of leading will always be accepted by your colleagues. Keep improving your communication skills. You don’t have to be liked, but your ideas and achievements should be respected.  
- Be visible and approachable to important people. Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Know when your contribution is important and how you can help others become leaders.

Films on Video**
**Film critic Nick James reviews some recent movies.**
**A. Abyss**  
Before Titanic, director James Cameron made a tense Cold War thriller about oil workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The friendly jokes and brave actions of foreman Bud and his team remind us of tough heroes in movies by Howard Hawks. The special effects and set design are very impressive, but the dialogue and characters are not as strong. Even though the film is well-made, the story feels like a simple B-movie.
**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This video release of the James Jones novel about the battle for Guadalcanal, directed by Andrew Marton, is interesting compared to Terrence Malick's new film. Malick's version is mystical and poetic, while Marton's film is more traditional but often closer to the book. He focuses on one soldier and his difficult relationship with his tough sergeant. Malick's film is richer and more complex, but Marton's version has some strong moments. The flashback where the soldier dreams of his wife is done in a way that some may find more effective than Malick's softer images.
**C. On Guard**  
This fun swashbuckler is loosely based on Paul Feval's 1875 novel. It is better than most musketeer movies. Fabrice Luchini plays a clever villain who causes trouble behind the scenes. Vincent Perez is a lively hero, even if he doesn't last long. Daniel Auteuil is a bit too serious for a fun movie, but he has his moments as a swordsman. The filmmakers use classic costume drama ideas with so much humor and charm that it works well.
**D. Character**  
This serious story is set in Rotterdam at the turn of the century. The detailed production and costumes make the film look like a museum piece. Jan Decleir plays the harsh bailiff Dreverhaven, who is cruel when evicting tenants. His difficult relationship with his son is the main part of the story, but the filmmakers focus too much on the details and not enough on the dark story.
**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This newly re-released video shows off director Leone's skills. The sound editing is especially good; every step, creaking floorboard, and barking dog is clear. The story is very harsh, and whenever it slows down, Morricone's great music brings excitement back. Morally, there is not much difference between the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Ell Wallach), as they all act selfishly in the post-Civil War West.
**F. The Longest Day**  
The publicity for this three-hour war epic boasts "Forty-eight International stars." With four directors and 23,000 extras, it feels too big. The early scenes, where the experienced soldiers wait for news about the invasion, are slow for both the audience and the soldiers. While it is impressive in terms of logistics, it is better suited for the big screen. Watching it on video does not give the same experience.

**BOOK A** Steve Martin's *Compelling Evidence* is very interesting. The main character is a lawyer who is trying to start a new job after leaving a big law firm. He has to defend his boss's wife when she is accused of killing her husband. The trial scenes are exciting, and the ending has a surprising twist. This is a great first book in a popular genre.
**BOOK B** *Curtains for the Cardinal* starts with a lot of action. It follows Sigismondo, a problem-solver for rich people in the Italian Renaissance. He gets involved in politics, church secrets, and a serious murder case. Even though the story is complicated and a bit too long, it is still very enjoyable.
**BOOK C** *File Under: Deceased* introduces a new detective, Leah Hunter, who is a tax inspector. She finds herself in a mystery when a strange man dies in front of her. Despite facing challenges and the disapproval of a local detective, Leah is brave and smart, making her a great character.
**BOOK D** *Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker features Spenser, a private investigator. He helps his friend Hawk get rid of drug dealers in a poor area of Boston. The dialogue is quick and clever, and while there are not many deaths, there is more thinking than usual. It is always high-quality entertainment from Parker.
**BOOK E** *False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann has detectives Pete Decker and Marge Dunn looking into a robbery at the home of a famous actress's daughter. The author's easy writing style and focus on unusual human behavior make this an enjoyable mystery.
**BOOK F** *Blood Red, Snow White* is written by husband and wife team Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It features another lawyer and a female client, but most of the action happens outside the courtroom. The lawyer becomes a victim as the story unfolds. It has all the classic elements of romance, money, and violence, making it a gripping suspense novel.
**BOOK G** *Dead for a Ducat* by Simon Shaw features actor Philip Fletcher as a target. A funny group of characters comes together to film a story about Robin Hood, but Philip feels this is not the right direction for his career. Simon Shaw usually entertains well, but this time the story is not as strong as his other works.
**BOOK H** *Fall Down Easy* is Lawrence Gough's best book in a while. Canadian police are searching for a clever bank robber who targets female bank tellers. The story builds tension slowly and shows the smart but troubled robber, making it much better than an average detective novel.

I might be too old for this, but here I go! At 34, Tim Pozzi has left a good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age are making this choice. This summer, I quit my job and decided to rent out my flat to travel in South East Asia for a year. You might think I’m lucky, but I’m 34 years old and I feel nervous. I have traveled before. After university, I spent two years backpacking in North and South America, and I wanted to do it again someday. But then I fell in love, started a career, bought a flat, and got used to earning money. I realized I was giving up my own happiness for my salary. When I quit my job, it felt like I was taking control of my life again. 
I have no ties now. Many of my friends are married with children. They wouldn’t want to change places with me, but they envy my freedom. I’m not in a relationship, and I don’t have big career goals. I feel like I should make the most of my freedom, at least for my friends! But why am I so nervous? First, I have to make all the arrangements. How can I let someone else live in my home? How do I organize renting it out? And I need to decide where to go. I tend to put things off, and I’m already behind my plan. I thought, “I might as well enjoy the summer in England,” and then, “Why not wait for the start of the football season?” 
It’s hard to cut emotional ties. I’m delaying because I wonder if I can still handle backpacking. Will I be able to live a simpler life? Will I feel out of place among younger backpackers? Maybe not. More and more people in their late twenties and thirties in Britain want to leave their current lives and travel. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says that many people who always say, “I wish I had that chance” are realizing they can have it anytime. They just need to be brave, organized, and confident.
For Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, this trip is a chance to have fun before settling down. They bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. Danny says, “I’m ready to give up job security for this trip.” He knows he might return to the same job position, but he thinks it’s a risk worth taking. When he left his office, he threw his calculator into the river as a sign of freedom!
For Matt, who just left the Army, traveling for a year was a big change. He needed to change his way of thinking to live a normal life. There are many reasons for people my age to travel. Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development says that more people are working on short-term contracts. If your contract ends, you have nothing to lose. Some big companies even allow career breaks. They want their trained employees to come back instead of going to work for a competitor.
Dan Hiscocks, who runs a company that publishes stories of travelers, says many people in their thirties are thinking about their lives. If you’re not happy with your job, it’s not just about sticking with it anymore. People know there are opportunities, and a job isn’t forever. Traveling gives a chance to think about life. 
Is wanting to travel just a sign that my generation can’t handle being adults? Jennifer Cox doesn’t think so. She believes it shows we are better educated and more stable. We care less about just paying bills and more about living a balanced life. We are asking ourselves, “Is this what I want?” Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher going to Central America for a year, doesn’t think he’s running away. He wants to find things for himself. But he feels nervous about leaving his comfortable routine, like going to the office every day and chatting with everyone over coffee.
I understand Ben’s worries about leaving a stable life. I’m not sure I would be going on this journey if I hadn’t found my boss so difficult. Jennifer Cox says this is common. Often, something happens, like a breakup or losing a job, that pushes people to travel. It took a little push for me to start, but now I feel excited about the next 12 months. No matter what happens, I will be happy that I took this chance. I believe many of us older backpackers feel the same way.

'Plugging in the Home'**
Georgina McGuiness took a long break from her job as a journalist and felt lost with all the new technology. In this text, she shares how she changed her home into a good place to work.
The Christmas before last, I turned 37 and realized that I needed to restart my career in journalism. I felt like my skills were old-fashioned, stuck in the 1980s when typewriters were common. I saw that many job ads wanted experience with desktop publishing, which I did not have. I thought it would be easier to host a seminar on nuclear physics than to use a computer for layout. I was not good with technology; even calculators confused me, and I didn’t know how to use the timer on the video.
I knew I had to change quickly. I thought leaving home before my children would be hard, but then I entered a competition in a local newspaper. To my surprise, my family and I won a computer package. We received a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We jumped into this new world of the Internet and started chatting with people from around the world. The children stopped watching TV, and I set up a small office in the kitchen with a phone, a fax machine, a CD-ROM, and a modem to connect to the Internet. I had everything I needed to work from home while still taking the kids to school.
My children were already good with computers from school, but I was nervous. I thought I would lose my work if I pressed the wrong button. I was wrong. I learned the basic skills I needed, and it was easier than I thought. With practice, I got better every day. I started writing articles for a magazine, contributing about two articles a month. I felt proud that I could balance work and family life.
How has the computer helped me? In school, my desk was always messy, and I often lost important papers. Now, the computer helps me stay organized. I can keep track of my income and expenses with spreadsheets, and I save time with ready-made invoices and letterheads. As a journalist, being online allows me to research stories, ask for information, and discuss working from home with people worldwide.
However, working from home has its downsides. I can feel lonely without face-to-face contact. There are also distractions, like household chores, and sometimes my children argue about who gets to use the computer. Still, many people in my neighborhood are buying computers, not just for learning and fun, but also for work. 
A report called PC Usage in UK Homes shows that home workers are often well-educated, around 38 years old, and most own a personal computer. Many have a CD-ROM, a laser printer, and a modem. I feel like I am doing well with my technology skills. One day, I might even send an article to a newspaper in Melbourne or publish my own magazine from home. The possibilities seem endless!

**The Tartan Museum**
The Tartan Museum is located in Edinburgh, Scotland. Its modern buildings look very different from the historic area around it. Sally Varlow visited the museum just before it opened to see what it was like inside.
You cannot miss the new Museum of Scotland. It is on the corner of Chambers Street in Edinburgh, with a big yellow tower and unique buildings. Last winter, people had mixed feelings about the building. Some called it a "masterpiece" or "stunning," while others were not so sure.
Now, as the inside is almost ready, people wonder if the exhibitions will be interesting. The museum tells many stories through its historic objects, and there is a timeline to help visitors understand. However, it does not let national pride take over the display of important items, like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels.
Dr. David Clarke, who is in charge of exhibitions, believes that visiting the museum should be enjoyable for everyone, not just experts. He wants to show the truth about history, so there are no fake scenes or displays. Visitors will see what experts know about the past.
The challenge is whether the stories of the objects can be told well with just explanation panels and multimedia displays. With less than three days before the opening, it is hard to tell. However, some things are clear. The views of Edinburgh Castle are amazing, and the galleries are designed to flow into each other, with pale walls and deep display cases. Natural light comes in through special windows, making it a pleasant space to explore.
The museum also has a Discovery Centre, thanks to a group of children aged 9 to 12 from all over Scotland. They wanted to create a fun experience, and while they could not have rides through the displays, they did get a hands-on area for kids.
On the top floor, there is a gallery that changes every three years. It features objects chosen by Scottish people that have had a big impact on life in Scotland during the twentieth century. Suggestions included an electric guitar, televisions, and favorite toys. While this idea is fun, it may not address more serious topics.
Overall, Dr. Clarke believes that objects can tell stories about the past better than anything else. The modern architecture of the museum looks great from the inside and the top, but whether it fits well in its location is still up for debate.

The end of print newspapers may take a long time. "Transition" is a nice word that means moving from one place to another. Change can be scary for some people, but it can also be a good thing. However, the change from print newspapers to online news is not easy. Many people believe that this change will happen eventually because print newspaper sales are going down, while visits to their websites are increasing. For example, newspapers like The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have seen their print sales drop by 8% to 10% each year, but their websites are getting more visitors.
However, there are some things that do not fit this picture. A recent survey showed that the total number of newspapers sold around the world actually went up by 1.1% last year, reaching 512 million copies a day. While sales in Western countries have dropped, sales in Asia have increased. News magazines, which many think are struggling, also saw a 5.4% increase in sales.
The same is true for books. E-readers like Kindle are very popular, and their sales have increased a lot this year. But when bookstores looked at the sales of physical books, they found that the sales were only down by 0.4%. This shows that people are buying both e-books and physical books.
Many people think that young people are not reading newspapers anymore, but this is not completely true. The latest survey shows that nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 still read the main national newspapers. Different countries have different trends. In Britain, newspaper sales have dropped by 10.8%, but in Germany, the drop is only 7%, and in France, it is just 3.1%.
Media experts in America used to think that online advertising would help newspapers succeed online. But now, online advertising is actually going down. Many US newspapers have started charging for online access. The best way to get people to pay for online news seems to be to offer both a print copy and online access together. This means that print newspapers are still important for selling online subscriptions. Print ads also make much more money than online ads.
However, it is hard for newspaper companies to manage both print and online versions because it is complicated and expensive. But print newspapers still have a strong presence, and it is harder for them to be noticed online.

**Photographing People**
People are the most interesting subjects for photographs. A picture with a person is usually more engaging than one without. However, taking good photos of people can be challenging. The photographer must pay attention to actions, gestures, and expressions. Sometimes, just having a camera can make people act differently.
**A. Grouping People**  
When taking group photos, avoid straight lines. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances. You can also have some people sit or kneel in front so that all faces are visible.
**B. Posing for Pictures**  
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by suggesting comfortable positions, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.
**C. The Right Approach**  
Do not pretend you are not taking a picture when it is obvious you are. This can make people feel tense. Most people will agree to have their picture taken, but they might feel self-conscious. You may need to guide them to look at the camera.
**D. Eye Contact**  
A photo looks better if the subject is looking at the camera. Ask them to look into the lens, but they don’t have to smile. If they seem distracted, remind them just before you take the picture. You can also say something funny to get a natural reaction.
**E. Candid Concentration**  
Instead of looking directly at the camera, the subject can focus on something else in the picture. This can make the photo feel more natural, as if you are capturing a moment without them noticing.
**F. Expressions and Gestures**  
Expressions and gestures tell us a lot about a person. A laughing child can make viewers smile, while a sad face can create sympathy. Look for common expressions like shrugs, winks, or smiles; they are a quick way to communicate feelings.
**G. Situation Interest**  
While close-up shots of a person can be powerful, the background can add more context. When including a background, make sure it does not distract from the subject. A wide-angle lens can help make the subject stand out.
**H. Interaction**  
Good photos often happen when people are interacting, like talking or laughing together. Look for moments of connection, such as eye contact or a friendly gesture.
**I. People and Places**  
Many photos of people are taken during trips. To improve these pictures, use a wide-angle lens and step back to include the background, like a building or a mountain. Make sure the people are close enough to be the main focus without hiding the background.
**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**  
Decide why you want to take the picture. If it’s to remember someone you met on holiday, a clear posed picture is good. However, family photos can be more fun if they capture real moments instead of stiff poses. Candid shots often bring back memories better than posed ones.

Under Sarah's Spell**
Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist. This means she creates paintings that trick the eye and look very real. In this interview with Joanna Watt, we learn more about her.
Not many artists do not sign their work unless someone asks them to. Sarah Janson is one of these artists. She does not care about being seen as a great artist. She believes, "It's not the artist who is important, but the work." Sarah is very humble and would like people to think her paintings create themselves. This makes it hard for her to do an interview. She says, "I just don't like to shout about myself," and she gets nervous when asked to be photographed.
After a little time, Sarah feels more comfortable, and the interview becomes fun and interesting. She has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. Before that, she studied drawing at art school for two years and worked in graphic illustration. However, she was not happy with illustration and started working with a decorator named Jim Smart. He asked her to create one trompe-l'oeil painting, and that changed everything for her. She decided to work on her own, not knowing exactly what would happen, but feeling it was the right choice.
Sarah's skills in observing details helped her become a good trompe-l'oeil artist. She says, "People often ask me where they can learn trompe-l'oeil. But no one can teach you. Trompe-l'oeil is the school of life. It's all about observation." She believes that you are always learning. She is honest about her weaknesses, saying, "I can't paint bread; it always looks like grey concrete." She also struggles with math, especially when she had to measure for a big project at Lulworth Castle. She thought, "You're not Michelangelo. Who do you think you are?"
Sarah often talks about herself in the third person. After finishing a big ceiling, she thought, "Well, I didn't do it, she did." Her trompe-l'oeil paintings are very special and different from others. She has many important projects for companies and private clients. Much of her work is inspired by buildings. For example, she created a trompe-l'oeil dining room based on a Venetian palace and a painting that makes it look like you can walk into two more rooms.
However, there is a risk with trompe-l'oeil art. Once people understand the trick, they might lose interest. Sarah knows this and says, "Trompe-l'oeil has to do two things. First, it must draw you in; it's got to trick you. Secondly, it has to hold you and engage your imagination." She believes that trompe-l'oeil art should also be personal for the client. "I love the interaction with clients; that is where the ideas are born," she explains. Some clients have clear ideas, while others do not. She listens to them and tries to understand their imagination. Many clients become friends because she spends a lot of time with them while working.
Sarah appreciates her clients, saying, "I am very grateful for the mad ones who have let me loose on their walls." They are happy with her work, which is why she is always busy, even if she does not like to talk about her talent. "I really don't like to shout about myself," she says again. "Like my work, I am very restrained. I don't want it to shout. You become bored with things that shout." This may be true, but you could never get bored with Sarah or her art. Her work deserves to be more well-known, and I am happy to share it.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**
Daniel Goleman talks about the important "people skills" needed to succeed in our jobs.
A. The rules for work are changing. We are now judged not only by how smart we are or how well we are trained, but also by how we manage ourselves and interact with others. This new way of judging is used to decide who gets hired and who does not. It helps to show who is likely to be a top performer and who may not do as well. These new rules are important for our future job opportunities. They focus on social skills and personal qualities, like being proactive, understanding others, being flexible, and convincing people. These skills are part of what we call emotional intelligence.
B. In a time when job security is low, personal qualities are becoming more important at work. For many years, people have talked about these qualities using different names, like "character" or "soft skills." Now, we have a clearer understanding of these skills, which we call "emotional intelligence." This means being aware of and managing our own feelings and the feelings of others, and using these feelings to guide our actions. In the workplace, emotional intelligence includes self-awareness, self-control, motivation, empathy, and good social skills. Some people think it just means "being nice," but sometimes it means being honest, even if it is uncomfortable. It is not about expressing all our feelings freely, but about managing them so we can work well together.
C. More businesses are realizing that encouraging emotional intelligence is very important for good management. The more complicated the job, the more emotional intelligence matters. If someone lacks these skills, it can affect their ability to use their knowledge and skills. Many people have succeeded despite having low emotional intelligence, but as work becomes more complex and requires teamwork, companies that work well together have an advantage. In today’s workplace, where teamwork and good customer service are important, emotional intelligence is essential for success in every job around the world.
D. Unlike IQ, which does not change much, emotional intelligence can grow as we learn from our experiences. Studies show that most people become better at managing their emotions, motivating themselves, and understanding others over time. This growth in emotional intelligence is often called maturity. We can learn these skills and use them to help us in our careers, especially when job stability is uncertain. Emotional intelligence is not a magic solution for companies that are not competitive, and it does not guarantee success. However, if we ignore the human side of work, nothing else will work as well as it could.

'Should the media make money from content they do not own? Digital cameras and camera phones have made it easier to take pictures of important news events. Social media has changed how people share these photos. Now, some journalists look at social networks for images when news happens quickly. However, some reporters have used photos from users without asking for permission. There are rules that say images on social media can be used without permission in special cases or when there is strong public interest, but people still argue about whether this is right. Research shows that about one in ten people would take pictures or videos of a news event, which means user-generated content (UGC) is important for the future of the media. To keep a good relationship with the public, the media should make sure that people are paid fairly for their work and that they always ask for permission.'

Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**
Acupuncture is a practice that is over two thousand years old. It comes from traditional Chinese medicine, which also includes herbal medicine, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is often used to help with pain, and many doctors in the West use it for this purpose. 
**A. What is it about?**  
Traditional Chinese medicine believes that health is when the mind, body, and spirit are in balance. They say that energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), flows through the body along paths called meridians. There are twelve main meridians connected to different organs, and many smaller ones that carry Qi to every part of the body. If the flow of Qi is blocked or weak, a person may feel weak or become ill. When you visit an acupuncturist, they will check your pulses, look at your tongue, and ask about your health, feelings, and habits. They use very thin needles that go into the skin and may also use heat from herbs or pressure on certain points to help the flow of Qi.
**B. Over three hundred points**  
The points where needles are placed are connected to the meridians and may not be near the area that hurts. People often feel a mild ache or tingling when the needle is moved. This can be done by hand or with a machine. Acupuncturists believe this feeling means the needle has reached the Qi. There are over three hundred points on the main meridians and many more that are used less often.
**C. Science explains it**  
Even though not all doctors believe in traditional Chinese medicine, many accept that acupuncture can help with pain. Scientists have found some reasons why it might work. For example, they think that stimulating certain nerves can block pain signals from reaching the brain. Some believe that acupuncture can release natural pain-relieving chemicals in the body.
**D. What type of pain can be treated?**  
Many people with long-term pain try acupuncture when other treatments do not work. It is often used for back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also say they can help with menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in terminally ill patients.
**E. Modern use for an ancient treatment**  
Although acupuncture has been used in China for a long time, using it instead of anesthesia during surgery started in the 1950s. This helped convince some doctors outside China that acupuncture is effective. In China today, acupuncture is used in many types of surgeries, including tonsillectomies and heart surgery. It can be used alone, with electrical stimulation, or with medicine. Some people say it reduces pain, but results can vary. Acupuncturists say that acupuncture does not have the side effects of regular anesthesia, and recovery is faster.
**F. Always effective?**  
Like many alternative therapies, it is hard to study acupuncture. However, studies show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it helpful for chronic pain. Acupuncturists agree with this success rate. They know it may not work for everyone, and some people respond better than others. For long-term pain, it usually takes six to seven visits to feel real relief, but some improvement can happen after just two or three visits.
**G. A different approach to pain**  
Western and Chinese medicine see pain differently. Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just the pain. They spend time diagnosing the problem and looking for weaknesses in the Qi. They also consider outside factors that may affect the pain, like weather or the type of pain (sharp, dull, constant, etc.). This is different from how most doctors approach pain.
**H. Traditional or not?**  
Some doctors have training in traditional acupuncture, while others, including many general practitioners, prefer scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe that using traditional methods can lead to better and longer-lasting results, but this is hard to measure in studies. It is important to choose a qualified acupuncturist, who should refer you to a medical doctor if needed.

P.D. James is a famous crime writer. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James. She seems calm and confident, but she is actually quite shy. She says that Adam Dalgliesh, the detective in her books, is like her, or how she would be if she were a man. Dalgliesh likes to solve crimes alone, just like P.D. James prefers to write alone. She needs privacy to write and can do it anywhere as long as she is alone.
P.D. James does not agree that she is the best-known crime writer in Britain, even though many people read her 12 detective novels. She admires her friend Ruth Rendell and enjoys her books, especially those written under the name Barbara Vine. She also likes books by women writers like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner, but she also reads male authors like Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh, who she thinks were great writers.
P.D. James became successful later in life. She was 42 when her first crime novel, Cover Her Face, was published. She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge. She met her husband there, who was a student. She chose Cambridge as the setting for one of her books, An Unsuitable Job For A Woman.
Her life has not always been easy. Her husband, Connor Bantry White, returned from World War II very sick. She had to work long hours to support him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane. Even though she had many ideas for stories, she did not have time to write. Her husband’s parents helped take care of the children during this tough time.
While working full-time for the National Health Service, she used her strong organizational skills. She managed five clinics and then worked for 11 years at the Home Office, first in the Police Department and then in the Criminal Law section. While working in forensic science, she became used to seeing dead bodies. However, she was not interested in death itself; she liked the challenge of writing a crime novel. She has always enjoyed reading detective stories and wanted to be a writer.
P.D. James did not want to write about her own difficult life. She thought writing detective stories was a good way to learn how to be a serious novelist. She realized that she could follow the rules of a classic detective story and still write a meaningful novel about people. She believes that writing detective stories helps to bring order to chaos. Solving a crime shows that life is important, even if the person is not likable. She thinks that nobody really likes violence.

**The Pen is Mightier than the Psychoanalyst**
The study of handwriting to understand a person's character is becoming more popular. In some countries, if you apply for a job, you will likely be asked to provide a sample of your handwriting. This handwriting sample can help decide if you are suitable for the job. Handwriting analysis, also known as graphology, is considered a real science in many places. Researchers believe it can help show certain health problems, like heart disease and cancer, and can reveal emotional issues.
More companies are using handwriting analysis to help with job interviews. Many big companies now hire graphologists to look at the handwriting of job candidates. However, many doctors and psychiatrists are not sure about the value of graphology. Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist for over 20 years, thinks they should take it more seriously. She believes handwriting can show psychological traits and some medical conditions. She says, "Handwriting can indicate social class and intelligence. It can also help decide if a person should focus on arts or sciences and if they are honest or tricky."
According to Ms. Marne, graphology can help identify possible criminal behavior. She says, "Criminals often have disturbed handwriting, which can be poorly shaped. Many criminals come from difficult backgrounds and have emotional problems. This can show in childish handwriting or in writing letters multiple times." 
Ms. Marne claims she can tell if people are honest or manipulative just by looking at their handwriting. She says young male offenders often have high letters, which means they live in a fantasy world and dream of success. Graphologists can also see if someone is under a lot of stress or has violent tendencies. Handwriting can even help predict if someone might think about suicide. 
She explains that heart and lung problems can sometimes be seen in handwriting. "You cannot make a diagnosis from just one sample unless the writing is very shaky. But if the handwriting changes over time or if the signature looks different, it could mean something serious is happening." A big emotional upset can also change a person's signature for a short time.
Ms. Marne says handwriting can show other psychological traits. For example, people whose letters connect in a thread-like way may be clever but tricky. Those who write mostly in capital letters might be hiding their true selves. Light pressure in writing shows sensitivity, while unique handwriting shows confidence and creativity. Disconnected writing often means a person is a loner. Very small signatures can show insecurity, and circles over the letter "i" can mean someone wants attention.
Ms. Marne believes it takes six years of study to analyze handwriting well, along with empathy and intuition. She thinks more research is needed to make graphology a proper science. She believes this will happen soon. "It is actually more accurate than psychoanalysis because you can learn a lot about a person’s history and emotional problems without asking them questions that they might not answer truthfully."
However, even though this information is interesting, there is not much strong evidence to support these claims. Some psychiatrists are very critical of graphology. They say handwriting is just a result of education and the way writing is taught, and it does not have any other meaning.

**Is your office working well?** Fresh air and good chairs are important for a happy and healthy workplace, according to a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they are. We had three experts with us: a building health consultant, an ergonomist (who studies working conditions), and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions.
**Office A: Advertising Agency**  
*Building Health Consultant:* This office is very simple; it has no central heating and no mechanical ventilation. The windows open to the street. It is surprising that this office works well, but the small team of seven people seems happy. They change the environment by opening doors or using electric heaters, just like at home. This may be the reason they are happy; they have created a comfortable working space without too many rules.  
*Ergonomist:* The furniture is mismatched and some pieces are not good for sitting. Many chairs are old and broken. However, the workers have different tasks, like meeting clients and making presentations, which helps them avoid boredom and tiredness.  
*Occupational Psychologist:* The staff enjoy the variety of work and the size of the office. It is small enough to know what others are doing but big enough to work alone. The office looks nice and is fun, showing both efficiency and creativity.
**Office B: News Service**  
*Building Health Consultant:* This office is not very exciting, but it is comfortable and the staff do not dislike it. The air quality is good, partly because there is a No Smoking policy.  
*Ergonomist:* The company has hired an ergonomist, so the chairs are good and the lighting and computers are fine. The space is okay, but the layout could be better. However, the office feels impersonal with plain grey walls.  
*Occupational Psychologist:* The walls are mostly bare, except for some planners and a poster about maternity rights. Most staff have worked there for at least five years and relationships are good. The office could be better if desks were arranged to help share information.
**Office C: Bank**  
*Building Health Consultant:* This office gets mixed reactions from workers. It feels like being in a glass box, where people can see each other. The air is not stale, even with smokers nearby.  
*Ergonomist:* The office is very standard and not inspiring. The desks are okay, but some chairs are not good for computer work. The computer screens are not set up well for modern use.  
*Occupational Psychologist:* The staff support each other and have good technology. There are many awards on display. The office has a serious look with wood paneling and brown carpet, but it is busy with activity.
**Office D: Newspaper**  
*Building Health Consultant:* This office has many problems. The air conditioning does not work well, causing big temperature changes. The space is messy, and many people do not have enough desk space. It is very dusty, and the roof collects dust that falls on people below.  
*Ergonomist:* The furniture looks more like it belongs in a workshop than an office. Many chairs are not good for people using computers, especially shorter people. Most chairs are old and do not adjust well.  
*Occupational Psychologist:* The office has old brown chairs and dirty carpets. It needs a good cleaning, and individual successes should be recognized more. The air conditioning needs to be fixed because there are many smokers. When we visited, there were not many conversations; everyone seemed stressed and focused on deadlines. The company should encourage teamwork.

**Chewing Gum Culture**
Chewing gum is popular and people in America chew about 12 million sticks every day. This ancient habit has become a big business. Each stick of gum has less than ten calories, but it is considered food and must follow the rules of the American Food and Drug Administration.
Today, most gum is made from synthetic materials, which means it is not natural. These materials include pine resins and softeners that help keep the flavor and improve the texture. However, this was not always true. The ancient Greeks chewed a gum-like substance from the bark of the mastic tree, which grows mainly in Greece and Turkey. Women in Greece used mastic gum to clean their teeth and freshen their breath.
American colonists learned to chew resin from spruce trees, following the example of the Native Americans in New England. In the early 1800s, pieces of spruce for chewing were sold in the eastern United States, making it the first commercial chewing gum in the country.
Modern chewing gum started in the late 1860s when chicle was discovered. Chicle is a milky substance from the sapodilla tree found in Central America. Gum made from chicle was smoother and more enjoyable to chew, leading to the growth of a large industry. However, it has been hard to grow sapodilla trees in large amounts. As the chewing gum market grew, companies began to use synthetic alternatives.
Today, only a few chicle gatherers, called chicleros, still collect chicle. They have a difficult and dangerous job, walking for miles in very humid conditions. They face dangers like poisonous snakes and insects. The chicle fly is especially troublesome because it lays eggs in the gatherers' ears and noses. Despite these risks, experienced chicleros climb trees to collect the sap, which they carry back to a camp. There, they boil the sap until it becomes sticky and forms bricks.
Life at the camp is not easy. The workers eat a boring diet mostly made of maize and drink a local alcohol made from sugar cane. Even though their work is hard, chicleros worry about losing their jobs. Not long ago, the United States imported 7,000 tonnes of chicle each year from Central America. Last year, only 200 tonnes were collected in the whole Yucatan peninsula in Mexico.
As chewing gum sales have increased, manufacturers have turned to synthetic materials to save money and meet demand. Gum producers are also finding clever ways to sell their products. They claim that chewing gum helps people relax, gives them energy, and reduces stress. During both world wars, soldiers were often given gum. One of the biggest claims is that chewing gum can help reduce tooth decay. 
When we eat, plaque acid forms, which can harm our teeth. Our saliva helps protect our teeth by neutralizing this acid and providing minerals. Gum makers say that chewing for 20 minutes can increase saliva flow. Research is ongoing to create new textures and flavors. Glycerine and other vegetable oils are now used to make the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still use natural ingredients. In America, 137 square kilometers are used just to grow mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**REMOTE HOTELS**
A. **INDIA - GHANERAO HOTEL, RAJASTHAN**  
Ghanerao Hotel is located in a small village near the Aravalli Hills. The hotel combines the calm of an English country house with Indian culture. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years, and now Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests. The hotel has basic facilities, like hot water from a bucket, but this simplicity makes it special.
B. **NEW ZEALAND - HERMITAGE HOTEL, MOUNT COOK**  
One of my favorite hotels is the Hermitage Hotel on New Zealand's South Island. I found it by chance while climbing. After climbing a glacier, I was surprised to see this hotel in a beautiful and wild area. It was amazing to come down from the mountain tired and find such luxury, with a man playing music on the piano.
C. **MAURITIUS - PARADIS HOTEL**  
The Paradis Hotel is located on a quiet peninsula in the south-west of Mauritius. The road to the hotel goes along the coast, passing empty beaches. The hotel is large and offers many free water sports, but you can easily find peace on its nine kilometers of private beach. In the evening, when everyone has left, you can relax on the beach and feel far away from everything.
D. **ST LUCIA - LADERA HOTEL**  
The Ladera Hotel in St Lucia has a stunning view of the Caribbean Sea. It is quiet and located high up at 1,000 feet. The open rooms have a view between the two peaks of the Pitons. The hotel has a colonial style with wooden furniture and four-poster beds.
E. **TURKEY - THE SPLENDID HOTEL, ISTANBUL**  
The Splendid Hotel is on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, a great place to escape the noise of Istanbul. The islands are just an hour away by boat and have no cars, only horse-drawn carriages. The hotel is a beautiful wooden building with red domes. Although it is a bit old now, it still has a lot of charm.
F. **FRANCE - CHATEAU D'ETOGES, EPERNAY**  
In the small village of Etoges, there is a lovely seventeenth-century chateau surrounded by a moat with swans. This chateau has 20 unique rooms, some with four-poster beds. They offer special weekend rates that include breakfast, dinner, and complimentary champagne.
G. **KENYA - THE FAIRVIEW HOTEL, NAIROBI**  
The Fairview Hotel in Nairobi is a comfortable place for travelers. It is not fancy but has a nice atmosphere. Many guests come to relax after a safari and often decide to stay longer. The hotel has beautiful gardens and is a great place to enjoy the sunset while having a drink and a hearty dinner.
H. **ITALY - HOTEL SPLENDIDO, PORTOFINO**  
The Hotel Splendido has welcomed many famous guests, including movie stars. This old monastery turned hotel is still very special. It offers simple but delicious food and has beautiful Persian rugs and homemade pasta.

Sue Brown is a hotel inspector. Christopher Middleton watched her during an inspection. One minute into the inspection, things are already going wrong for the Globe Hotel, but the staff do not know it yet. The receptionist is busy talking on the phone and does not notice Sue and Christopher. Sue whispers, "She hasn't even acknowledged us. Very poor." This is a common mistake that Sue has seen many times in her 11 years as an inspector. She expects better from a hotel with three red stars, which means it is one of the best hotels.
Before they even enter, Sue feels something is wrong. The entrance is through a door with a buzzer, and the hallway is long and empty. "This is not what I expected," she says. Things get worse when the receptionist says, "We have no record of your booking." There are 15 rooms in the hotel, but only three are occupied. The room they are offered is not good. It is stuffy, and there is a big hole in the wall behind the wardrobe.
When Sue started her job, people called her "The Woman in Black," even though she never wore black. The next morning, after paying her bill, she tells the hotel manager, Robin Greaves, who looks scared when he sees her. He quickly apologizes for a bad smell in the lounge. "We think there’s a blocked drain," he says. Sue suggests that he should guide guests to another lounge instead of the one with the smell. Greaves takes notes and looks worried. He has only been at the hotel for five months and finds it hard to believe Sue when she says her feedback will help the hotel in the long run.
Not everything is bad. Sue praises Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the waitress, who shared interesting information about the hotel’s 400-year history. The dinner was also good enough to keep the hotel’s two-rosette food rating. Greaves asks, "What do we need to do to get three rosettes?" Sue replies, "Don’t serve a pudding that collapses." Greaves looks disappointed.
Sue's job is to tell the hotel what is wrong, even if it is hard to say. She remembers a time when a woman complained that Sue got her son fired. All Sue could say was that he served her apple pie with his fingers. Sometimes, she gets letters with false complaints about her. "You get used to it, but it still hurts," she says.
Sue must tell the hotel her findings verbally and also send a written report. The hotels pay for her advice. Even though it is a tough job, being recognized with red stars makes it worth it. Greaves is relieved to hear that Sue will not recommend taking away the Globe's red stars. The bad news is that another inspector will come back in two months to check if the problems have been fixed. "Good," Greaves says with a forced smile. "We’ll look forward to that."

Doug Scott is a mountaineer who shares his experiences of climbing the highest mountains on each continent, known as the Seven Summits. He started this journey later in life and will tell his story in the order he climbed them.
A. **Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**  
Doug and his climbing partner, Dougal Haston, were in a snow cave below the summit. Dougal started talking about sleeping bags, which Doug found strange since they were alone. He thought it was because of low oxygen. Doug began talking to his own feet, which were getting cold. They were worried about how to survive well. Over the next two days, Doug remembered their time on the summit ridge and felt confident climbing with Dougal. He focused on finding a good rhythm to reach the top.
B. **Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**  
This mountain is known to be very dangerous. In April 1976, Doug and Dougal arrived at the Kahiltna Glacier and spent four days carrying equipment and food. After the first day, they realized how hard their climb would be. They followed a route from 1967 but decided to take a new path to the summit. They climbed with everything on their backs, which was a new way to climb this mountain. After three days, Doug's sleeping bag was wet, and they were both struggling. Because of the low air pressure, it felt like they were much higher than they really were. Finally, they reached the summit and felt victorious.
C. **Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**  
In September 1976, Doug and his friend Paul Braithwaite flew to Nairobi to climb Mt. Kenya. However, they ended up climbing Kilimanjaro instead. They got lost in the thick jungle and were worried about finding water. On the second day, they found some arrows on trees and a rock pool, which made them very happy. They tried to climb a steep wall but decided to take a safer route to the summit.
D. **Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**  
In January 1992, Doug and his wife, Sharu, arrived at Punta del Inca. They met a guide named Phil who invited them to join his group to climb Aconcagua. After waiting for bad weather to pass, they started climbing. The Polish Glacier was icy and windy, so they chose to take a different route to avoid the glacier. They walked with many other climbers to the summit. The wind was strong, and they camped outside before heading back to base camp. There, they met a group planning to climb the Seven Summits, which made Doug think about doing the same.
E. **Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**  
Doug learned that climbing Vinson Massif could be funded by guiding others. In November 1992, his team traveled to the South Pole. During this time, the sun never sets, and the air is very fresh. On December 7, they started their climb. Despite strong winds and very low temperatures, they all reached the top in eight hours. However, they could only see a few meters because of a storm.
F. **Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**  
In the summer of 1994, Doug's team gathered in St. Petersburg. When they arrived at Elbrus, they had to pay a fee to their guide. After a few days of getting used to the altitude, they took a cable car up to 3,900m and then walked to a refuge at 4,200m. Two days later, they faced strong winds while climbing. They thought they reached the summit but found there was more to climb. They returned to the refuge and then descended the volcano.
G. **Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**  
On their trip to Carstensz, Doug and his team wanted to create a new climbing route and spend time with the local Dani people. They were warned about possible dangers, but they continued their journey. On May 12, the weather got better, and they climbed. Doug reached the summit by 11 am and received a standing ovation for completing his seventh summit. Mission accomplished!

**Style Merchants**
Style is important in our lives today, from our clothes to home decoration and accessories. Jo Foley shares some fashion trends for this year.
**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**  
Ned Ingham creates beautiful and romantic wedding dresses. He suggests that people should avoid traditional, stiff dresses and the frilly style. Instead, he recommends simpler designs. Ingham has been drawing and designing wedding dresses since he was a child. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to make clothes. You don’t have to be a bride to wear an Ingham dress; he also designs long evening dresses in modern colors and fabrics. For those who prefer classic styles, he offers a navy-blue summer suit, which has been popular for many years, but he makes it look fresh and new.
**Sally Quail: Jeweller**  
Sally Quail used to work for an art dealer but has no formal training in jewellery. She started designing her own engagement ring when she couldn’t find one she liked. This led her to become a designer in 1990. Now, many famous people wear her jewellery. Her style features large semi-precious stones set in gold, creating beautiful necklaces, bracelets, and rings inspired by the 18th century. Recently, she has started using diamonds. "I wanted a diamond, and that is when I began working with them," says 36-year-old Quail.
**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**  
Lily Grimson has been in the fashion business for four years and has already had two of her bags chosen for a big design exhibition. All of her bags are handmade in the UK. A Grimson handbag is not just a bag; it is stylish and made from high-quality materials like calfskin and silk. Her bags are special because they combine style and care.
**Peter Little: Hairdresser**  
For over 20 years, Peter Little has styled the hair of many famous people. He believes that most women want hair that looks natural and is easy to manage at home. His goal is to make sure his clients look like they haven’t just come from a salon. However, his services are expensive, costing £250 for the first appointment, and there is a long waiting list. Peter has also created his own line of hairdryers and styling tools, so people can style their hair at home.
**Penny Pratt: Florist**  
Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop and also works as a flower consultant for supermarkets and restaurants. She has no formal training in floristry and left her teaching job 10 years ago to try something new. Her modern flower arrangements have won many design awards, helping her start her own London Flower School. She has also given successful lectures in Japan and the USA. She believes that flower arrangements should be simple but strong, with fewer leaves. For wedding bouquets, she advises that all flowers should be the same type.

**Five-Star Luxury and Modern Technology**
The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It was created by changing four large old houses into a hotel. This took a lot of research and nearly two years of work. The hotel has the latest technology to help both the staff and the guests.
Peter MacCann, the General Manager, wants his staff to know the guests' names. For more details about what guests like, he uses the hotel’s computer system. This system helps the hotel give special service to returning guests. It cost £250,000 to set up, but MacCann believes it will be worth it over time. He is happy with how well it works and the services it provides. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them when they come back.
Many hotel guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a high-tech system to control this. Guests can change the temperature in their rooms by three degrees around the normal 18°C. The front desk can also adjust the temperature anywhere between 14°C and 25°C.
Business guests will find the technology in their rooms very useful. MacCann thinks that about 65% of the hotel’s business will come from this group. To meet their needs, the hotel has put a business center in each room. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that can also copy and print, and a video-conferencing system.
Technology changes quickly, so the hotel has prepared for future improvements. They have added extra cables for new technology. The televisions are rented, so they can be replaced with newer models when needed. DVD recorders can also be updated.
Even with all this technology, MacCann wants guests to feel comfortable. The hotel has 145 large and well-furnished bedrooms that are welcoming. There is also a swimming pool, a gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.
The food at the hotel is very important. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. He has designed a new kitchen and improved the restaurant. The hotel also has better parking than before. This partnership is good for both the chef and the hotel. With great technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be successful.

An Eye for Detail**
Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. The large garden around her house gives her many ideas for her art. It is full of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. The two long flower beds along the path in the garden have a beautiful mix of colors and shapes. This is partly because the previous owners were good gardeners and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept the gardener, Danny. 
Susan says, "In fact, it was really his garden." She and Danny got along well. At first, he would say some of her ideas were not worth it, but when she told him she wanted to paint them, he understood her vision. 
Susan likes to focus on painting individual plants instead of the whole garden. Sometimes she paints a group of plants, but usually, she picks one flower and takes it to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which can take a few days. Then I bring in another one and build the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."
Her busiest time is spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. But she also finds beauty in how flowers change as they decay. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, they seem boring, but they change all the time."
Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and collected wildflowers from the countryside," she says. "I didn't like garden flowers back then; I thought they looked fake, like silk or plastic flowers. I was fascinated by how wildflowers could grow in tough places, like cracks in rocks."
Today, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they look at home there. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don’t break anything. 
With two art exhibitions coming up and plenty of inspiration in her garden, Susan has found it hard to spend time working in the garden. She now has an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Text:**
Many trees in the Brackham area fell during the strong storms in March. The town lost two big lime trees from the old market square. This change made the town center look very different, which upset some of the older residents. One of these residents was Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, who was the head of the local police. However, during the storm, Pelham was not in a good condition to notice the changes because he was very sick with bronchitis for the first time in his life.
When he first felt pain in his head and tightness in his chest, his wife, Molly, wanted him to see a doctor. But Pelham thought the police needed him and did not listen to her. This made him forget things and made him more irritable. Eventually, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. By then, he was too weak to argue. Soon after, he got his medicine and went home, where Molly sent him straight to bed.
On Thursday morning, when Molly told him that the walnut tree in their garden had fallen during the night, Pelham could not believe it. Later that evening, he asked if the house was damaged. He was relieved to hear it was not and then covered himself with the sheets. It was not until Saturday, when the medicine started to work and he felt better, that he noticed the living room looked different without the walnut tree.
The Pelhams' house was large and had a big garden. Pelham was happy he bought it because the garden felt private. But now, the storm had changed how he saw things. Before, the walnut tree made the living room look nice with interesting light and shadows. But without the tree, the room looked too bright, showing the old furniture they had brought from their last house. The view from the window was not nice either. The tall house next door, which was hidden by the tree, was now visible. It had ugly purple bricks and many windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams.
"Doesn't it look terrible?" Pelham said to his wife. But Molly, standing in the doorway, seemed more happy than upset. "That's what I've been saying since we moved here. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost."

Living in the Valley**
We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first noticed the dangers in the hills around us. It was the year when the storms came early, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe in our valley, protected by the hills. Soon, snow began to fall. Within a day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. It almost blocked our lane and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. But in the hills, the snow was much deeper and stayed longer. The wind was very strong up there. In our valley, we only felt sudden gusts of wind; the trees swayed, but their branches stayed strong. Still, we knew we had to be careful.
The snow and wind were annoying, but they did not really worry us. The river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently, was what we feared the most. It reminded us of what could happen if the water from the hills was not controlled by the dams built many years ago. Soon, the snow started to melt. Day by day, we saw dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. These clouds looked dangerous and warned us of what was coming. We had watched the sky enough; now we began to watch the river, which was getting fuller and wilder every day. The snow melted as more rain fell from the clouds, but the reservoir in the hills was filling up and getting close to overflowing.
Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. It was like a small Niagara Falls, as the water rushed over the dam and into the stream below. The river looked wild as the water poured down towards our cottage. Just a couple of meters from our home, the stream was deeper than we had ever seen, rushing angrily at its banks. For three days, we hoped it would stay below its edge. Luckily, our hopes were answered as the dam held, and the water began to go down.
In the past, before the dam was built, the river had flooded nearby villages many times. Now, the dam controls the river, and usually everything is fine. The water from the hills, caused by snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam, with only a little overflow sometimes. Because of this protection, we can enjoy the big clouds over the valley and feel safe in our home.

Film critic Mark Adams looks back at his ten years of work as a film critic for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing articles about films for The Front Page was my first real job. Before that, I wrote reviews for novels in other newspapers, films for a magazine, and did some work for the radio. That is how I met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page. He also worked in radio and television. He hired me, but Tom was not mainly a journalist, so he was not very careful when choosing his staff.
At first, Tom wanted a team of critics to cover different art forms like books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would have a weekly lunch to choose what to write about from the artistic material Tom wanted us to cover. There would also be guests to make it more social. It felt like a dream to be part of a new newspaper. I thought it was strange that a new paper could start in a busy market. I even thought a rich person wanted to help me and was pretending to hire me because I lacked confidence. The first time I saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground with one of my reviews, I felt very shy.
Tom's idea for a team of critics did not work out. It was a good idea, but we did not meet as planned, so we communicated by phone. It turned out that people preferred to have one reviewer for each subject, so I chose to focus on film. Without Tom's help, we would not have the current setup, where I write a long weekly piece about one film. I like this way of working. I would not enjoy the usual film critic job, which means watching every new film. That routine would make me bored quickly. I would not want to sit in a screening room on a Monday morning thinking, "What terrible film do I have to watch now?" 
The time I have allows me to develop my ideas or, if the week is not interesting, to create something from nothing. But what is my role in the public eye? I think people choose films based on the stars, the advertising, or the director. Some people are loyal to certain types of films. It is rare for someone who dislikes westerns to buy a ticket for one after reading a review, or for a romantic film lover to avoid a love story because of a review. So, if a film review is not really a guide for consumers, what is it? I do not feel I have to be "right" about a movie. I also do not think there should be a set number of "great" or "bad" films each year. All I need to do is present my opinion. I am not a judge, and I do not want to be one.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers? Because "it's fun." 
Melanie Sears is a teenager who loves endurance sports. She is looking for a training partner for triathlons, preferably another girl. The partner should enjoy running long distances (like 15 kilometers), swimming in cold water, and cycling long distances (100 kilometers). It is important to be able to do all three sports without taking a break.
Triathlons are becoming very popular in the Olympics. Many people watch athletes swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers without stopping. It looks hard, but why do triathletes push themselves so much? Melanie, who is 17 and does well in school, has not yet learned the usual answers about personal satisfaction and mental challenges that many athletes say.
"You swim 1500 meters, then run out of the water and jump on your bike, still wet. Of course, then you freeze. After the 40-kilometer bike ride, you have to run 10 kilometers, which is long when you are tired. But it's great fun, and it's all worth it in the end," she says.
Melanie entered her first triathlon when she was 14. "I won the junior section, but I was the only junior there. It seemed easy, and I waved at my friends as I went around." Feeling confident, she entered the National Championships. She had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, but she did not win. "I was following a man, and suddenly we ended up in the sea. We realized we had gone the wrong way. I ended up cycling 20 kilometers too far. I cried while running." But she did not give up and is determined to keep trying. "Sometimes I wish I could stop because then the pain would be over, but I am afraid that if I stop once, I will want to stop again."
Steve Trew, the sport's director of coaching, admires her determination. "I tested her fitness, and she worked so hard on the running machine that it finally threw her off into a wall. She gave it everything, but most people stop when they can't go any further. She just kept going."
Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but much slower at cycling. That's why I'm working hard on it." She is trying to convince her parents to buy a special bike for £2,000 (with a £1,000 discount) so she can compete in national 25 km and 100 km races later this year.
