He looked stressed as he approached a woman reading a book. He asked her if she was going to Philadelphia, and she said yes. Then he asked her for a favor. I stood a little away, pretending to check my wrist, even though I didn’t have a watch. The woman seemed cautious, and the man noticed. He said, “It’s nothing too difficult, I promise!”
They announced my train, and people started moving toward Gate E, pulling their bags behind them. The man explained to the woman, “My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, but when I got home, my wife was upset. My daughter forgot her passport and called from the station. She didn’t know what to do.”
The woman listened sympathetically. I thought it was strange. Why didn’t he just go himself? The woman asked him, “Why don’t you go yourself?” He replied, “I can’t leave my wife alone. She’s in a wheelchair.” I thought this was a weak excuse. 
I noticed the man was holding a padded envelope, not a regular one. It looked like it was stapled shut. I thought to myself, “Be careful, lady.”

'Gary and Me'**
John Moore is the owner of a restaurant, and he talks about his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef. John believes that everyone gets a chance in life. Gary had his chance with cooking, and John had his chance to run a restaurant. When John found out about a restaurant for sale, he quickly went to see it. The place was in bad condition, but it was perfect for his plans.
Running the restaurant reminded John of his childhood. He remembers being sad when his mother went to work in a factory and left him alone. Because of this, he wanted to have time for family. John's wife took care of their children and managed the accounts while he ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always made time to eat together as a family. This helped their children, Gary and Joe, become confident. From a young age, they would talk to the regular customers.
Gary was a lively child. When he was about seven, he jumped into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and hurt himself. As he grew older, he had to earn pocket money. He started with small jobs and by age ten, he was working in the kitchen every weekend, which gave him a lot of money at school. He was very disciplined and often woke up before his father. In a family business, everyone helps out, and John liked seeing Gary work.
Gary was not very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. By age 15, he was as skilled as the adult cooks and sometimes even managed the kitchen. He could make over a hundred meals, and John knew Gary would work in catering because he had talent. When Gary needed to do work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant.
Recently, Gary started playing the drums and formed his own band. John worries about what will happen to Gary's cooking if the music becomes successful. He advised Gary to focus on one thing at a time. John told him that if he wanted to achieve something, he needed to do it by age 30, or it might be too late.
At 17, Gary went to catering college. On his first day, he finished his work quickly while the other students were still learning. He even helped others with their tasks. Everyone is amazed at how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become. John is very proud of him. He always tells Gary that if you want something, you must work hard for it because nothing is given for free. Gary has seen his chance and taken it.
As children grow up, parents hope they listen to their advice. John thinks that if Gary remembers even a little of what he has said, it is a good thing. He is happy with the person Gary has become.

**Finding a Flat in Dublin**
Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very hard. The best way to find one is through personal contacts. If you know someone who knows someone who is moving out, that can help. But if, like Jo, you just arrived in Dublin, you might not have any contacts. Jo had to stay in a hostel and look for a flat. For her, Dublin felt very new and unknown. She didn’t think about why she was going there. Everyone at school thought she would leave her small town. They wanted to escape and have a better life. Some of her classmates went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family helped them settle in. But Jo was going to Dublin alone.
Jo’s mother thought it would be good for her to stay in the hostel. It was run by nuns, so her mother believed she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel would be warm because they are often cold. Jo’s sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy for staying in a hostel for a whole week. But Jo didn’t know they were talking about her while she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was very close to her job at the post office and seemed too good to be true. Jo hoped it would be nice and that the people would like her and that it wouldn’t be too expensive.
There wasn’t a line for this flat because it was not just a "Flat to Let," but more like "Third Girl Wanted." The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked normal. It was a simple red-brick house with a basement. The flat was upstairs. As Jo climbed the stairs, a cheerful girl with a college scarf came down. "Desperate place," she said to Jo. "They’re both awful. Common as dirt."
"Oh," said Jo and continued up. "Hello," said the girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that stuck-up girl going out? I can’t stand her kind." 
"What did she do?" Jo asked. 
"She didn’t do anything. She just looked around and made a face, then said, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh voice. We wouldn’t want her here, would we, Pauline?" 
Pauline, who had a very colorful shirt, looked interesting to Jo. She had seen punks like her on O'Connell Street but had never talked to one before. 
"I’m Jo, I work in the post office and I called about the flat," she said. Nessa said they were about to have tea. She got three mugs; one had 'Nessa,' one had 'Pauline,' and the other had 'Other' written on it. "We’ll put your name on a mug if you come to stay," she said kindly.

Behind the Dolphin's Smile**
People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in seaside areas, movies, and TV shows. However, the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says that dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds talks about the decline of dolphin populations.
Dolphins are special to us. They are very smart animals, they can feel human emotions, and they make us dream of freedom in the ocean. Our love for dolphins has grown because of TV shows. First, there was Flipper, and now there is Darwin from Seaquest. But these happy images hide the real problems dolphins face in polluted and overfished seas.
The number of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has dropped by up to 89,000. You might think that such popular animals would be protected by law and cared for in special marine areas. Unfortunately, this is not true, and the lack of protection could lead to a big wildlife disaster.
There are forty different types of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, the most common dolphins are the striped dolphin, the common dolphin, the bottlenose dolphin, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The striped and common dolphins usually live far out in the open sea and are seen in small groups. We know very little about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be seen often near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and were found along the Channel coast and in rivers in Britain, like the Thames. Now, they can only be found in a few places, like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that are left show signs of stress.
It is hard to know exactly why dolphin numbers are decreasing. Overfishing is reducing fish populations and threatening local fishing jobs, which also affects dolphins and porpoises. Porpoises need to find food quickly. If fish are taken from one area, they may not have enough time to find food in another area. They can also get caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. Many modern fishing methods use large nets that can float or move quickly through the water. In recent years, many dead dolphins have washed up on the beaches of France and Cornwall. Marks and cuts on their bodies show that they died because they were caught in these nets.
Dolphins can also store waste and other harmful substances in their bodies. For example, pesticides can build up in dolphins because they dissolve in fat. This means that when female dolphins produce milk, it can contain high levels of these poisons, which can harm their young. There is already one case of a young dolphin dying from its mother’s poisoned milk.
Another serious threat to dolphins comes from human activities. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their environment. In the ocean, noise from ships and oil drilling travels much better than in the air. This noise pollution may disturb dolphins in ways we do not fully understand.

**Getting Fit**
Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you feel balanced, especially when life feels busy and stressful. Many articles talk about fitness because it is really good for you. There are many reasons to exercise, and very few reasons not to.
Exercise helps improve your muscles and can change your body shape quickly. It makes your muscles stronger and helps you stand and sit better. It can also prevent injuries by fixing muscle imbalances. Exercise can improve specific areas like your thighs, stomach, and arms. It is good for your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.
You may have heard these reasons many times, but here is something new: exercise can help reduce feelings of depression and tiredness. It can also help you sleep better and manage stress. Exercise can even help with some health problems. 
If you are not convinced yet, just think about it: exercise is good for you. There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, jogging, or using weights. However, be careful not to train too hard or lift too much weight, as this can cause injuries. It is a good idea to talk to your doctor about what exercises are best for you.
Good posture is also important. If you do not have good posture, exercise will not help you look or feel better. A stiff or slouching body can look unattractive and may cause health issues. To improve your posture, imagine that a balloon is pulling the top of your head up. This can help you breathe better and make your body look slimmer.
Stretching is important too. It helps you move easily and keeps your muscles from getting hurt. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will become more flexible and fit. Stretching should be done slowly and carefully.
The best exercise routine includes warming up, stretching, a good workout, and cooling down afterward.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**
What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman stay away from home for many months? They are looking for the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, it is not easy to find producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman. Right now, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has had six months of almost non-stop rain. This has caused some unexpected problems. Newman said they had to buy an expensive piece of equipment so that if one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him back to safety. Their teamwork has created some of the best wildlife films on TV, like their popular film about leopards. While this film was being shown, they were already back in the field, this time following the shy jackal.
Traveling film-makers have been moving around the world to film exotic wildlife since television began. I talked to Newman about their partnership while he was having a rare meeting with other people at a safari lodge. "We do have some arguments, but we usually get over them quickly," he said about working with Amanda. Neither of them sees themselves as the leader, and they get along well because they both understand the animals in a similar way.
"When we travel, we have to set up our tents each night. But now we are staying in a more fixed camp. We leave at 5 a.m. each morning, so we make tea the night before and keep it warm in a flask." Their daily meals are pre-packed and heated by whoever is available. "We can be out for up to eight weeks at a time, so cooking can be a bit stressful," Newman said. It can be a tough life, but being in remote areas allows them to get close to the animals. Newman remembers filming a family of lions, where one lioness would often go off alone. When she returned, she would greet all the other lions and even their car.
Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift." Two years later, they began working together to film Arctic foxes. Since then, they have learned to spend four months in one location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they can start filming, they must submit a script for approval. "Amanda and I had a good working relationship from the beginning because we shared the same ideas and vision. We want to create a film that shows the true spirit of the place and the animals, and that touches people's hearts. I believe if you can make people feel something, that is better than just making them think."

**The Netball Captain**
In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day. She taught at a local school and then had a training session in a supermarket car park. I was surprised to hear about her training place. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I focus on my movements and my feet, so I don’t notice much else. I might see cars slow down a little, but that’s all."
Kendra said, "My whole life is about being my best for the Championships." She follows a strict schedule to be fit for the games. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries participating. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It is important to improve the reputation of netball in our country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure. The crowd will expect us to play well."
Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra believes they have always won against them, but she knows they are a strong team. The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. Kendra explained that the Championships will be tough. "You have to push yourself every day. There is no rest between games. In a series, you can still win if you lose the first game, but in the Championships, you only have one chance."
In the fifteen years she has played at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive now. Kendra said, "You don’t train hard to lose." But after the game, everyone is friendly. 
Netball is also using more science for fitness testing. Kendra said, "It is important for us to think and train like world-class players." As captain, she believes it is important to have a strong mindset and to lead by example. "I see my role as supporting and encouraging my team."
Kendra has planned her netball career carefully. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future, but right now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have tears in her eyes. Her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

In Hot Water**
Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and does research in marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemicals in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she goes down into a small steel vehicle to explore underwater volcanoes. 
Inside the vehicle, there is very little space. Rachel says, "I can reach out and touch the two pilots. We cannot stand up or move around, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up."
"If there is a problem and we need to get to the surface quickly, we can hit a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that goes up to the surface quickly. No one has tested it yet, but I think it would not be a nice journey."
Rachel remembers her first dive. She climbed into the vehicle on a ship with an instructor. He explained what to do in an emergency, like if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place five days away from the Canary Islands in the Atlantic Ocean, where there are many underwater volcanoes that blow out black smoke. The Russian team was dropping off equipment to study a project that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano.
When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers.' This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where hot water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It comes out at a speed of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees."
The only time Rachel felt scared was during her first dive with an American team. They were towing equipment when suddenly there was a loud explosion. She thought, "I'm going to die." They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they felt incredible relief—they were still alive!
"Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see the chimneys, I feel amazed. I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my Ph.D. When I finally saw them, it was an amazing feeling."

**Interview Tips**
First impressions are very important. Studies show that people make judgments about us in the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body language, how fast or slow we talk, our voice volume and tone, and the words we use.
Mary Pearce wanted to be a teacher. She worked hard to earn her degree and felt confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. On the day of the interview, she saw a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing, but she didn’t want to be late because she believes it is important to be on time. Unfortunately, Mary did not get the job. A friend who teaches at the school told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn’t take the time to look their best at an interview, what kind of teacher will they be?"
Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says that people who care about their appearance are more likely to care about their jobs. Many people think that what is inside is what matters, but in an interview, you should try to present yourself in the best way.
Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a big accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the job but did not get an interview. She thought it was a mistake and asked the Director of Personnel what happened. He told her that she did not fit the image of an office manager and suggested she improve her wardrobe before applying again. Janet was shocked because she believed she did a good job and that her clothes should not matter.
Movement and gestures also affect how an interviewer sees a candidate. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that only 7% of our message comes from the words we use, 38% from our voice, and 55% from our facial expressions. If our words and facial expressions send different messages, the listener will pay more attention to the non-verbal message. So, it is important that your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.
It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion and her interview went very well. She was offered the job right away. However, she was too excited and showed too much enthusiasm. The boss realized she would not turn down the offer, so he gave her a lower salary than she wanted. She believes she could have asked for more if she had controlled her excitement.
Finally, what we say and how we say it can help us succeed in an interview. David Artesio, a manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. For example, the annual report can tell you about the company’s work. Mentioning something that interests you during the interview can show your interest in the company.
Business consultant Marian Woodall advises having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences. She says, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and key points."

**A New Life**
**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He worked in the City for 14 years, but he found it was no longer fun. He did not plan to leave his job yet, but he was suddenly made redundant. He did not get a lot of money when he left, but it was enough to start his farm. His big chance came when he met the head chef of a well-known hotel restaurant. By supplying meat to them, he became more popular, and now he also sells meat online. Matt is happy to be out of the office, but he still works long hours, just like before.
**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he is an artist. He started painting as a hobby and found it much more exciting than his job. He decided to take redundancy and become an artist. A career counselor helped him, and he told the counselor that he did not want to go back to his old job. This surprised the counselor because most people in their forties need to find work quickly for money. Ron and his wife moved to the north of England, where they did not know anyone. They left their friends behind, but they are happy that their friendships have lasted, and many friends visit them now.
**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. She enjoyed being a lawyer and earned a lot of money, but the hours were very long. She did not want to become a senior partner and work even more, so she decided to leave. Many people thought she would get bored, but she has not. She keeps busy with deadlines for her fashion business, which helps her stay organized. Katherine feels happier and less stressed now, but she misses talking to colleagues. She loves being responsible for her work. If she does a bad job, she knows it is her fault. When she worked for a company, she cared, but now she cares even more because her name is on the products.
**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started working in finance at 22, but he did not find it rewarding. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he decided to resign and travel for a year. During that year, he thought about what he wanted to do. He was interested in health, so he visited gyms and talked to the owners about starting a business. He knew he needed qualifications to change careers, so he took courses in massage. Then he got a part-time job at the Life Centre. Paul has no regrets about his choice. He feels more in control of his life now and enjoys having peace of mind.

'Dedicated to Their Sports'**
Four young sports stars talk about their lives.
**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I have always loved sports. I played many sports, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football club, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My biggest moment was when I competed for my country in the youth team and won a medal. Unfortunately, it did not get much attention in the media, which was disappointing. I hoped to get some sponsorship because training is expensive. I train at home all winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It is fun because there are great facilities for athletics and the nightlife is good too. However, I have to be very disciplined. If my friends invite me out the night before training, I have to say no. I wish I could go, but being dedicated helps me in this sport. My main goal is to reach the next Olympics - that would be amazing.
**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often at dawn, so I have to avoid late-night parties. I don’t mind this too much, but I love sleeping in, and I usually have to give that up too. However, it is worth it because without this dedication, I might not have won the National Championships last year. After a win, I always celebrate with a big night out, and if I win money, I like to go somewhere nice. The sacrifices are worth it because winning that championship allowed me to present a surfing series on TV. Now, I guess I am a bit of a celebrity.
**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
When I am on a boat with my friends, we have a lot of fun. We are traditional and always celebrate our wins in style. Some people say we act a bit childish, but we do not look for media attention. Sometimes, reporters seem more interested in our celebrations than in our race results. I am away for eight months each year, so it is nice to come back and spend time with my friends who do different things. You cannot always focus on the sport; it is not healthy. I am known in the sailing world, but I am not recognized much in public. I would not like to be a celebrity. I do get nice letters from fans asking for signed pictures, and I reply to every one, even if it takes time.
**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It feels great to walk onto the court and hear the crowd cheering for me. At my last tournament, it got a bit crazy with many people around. I do enjoy being recognized by fans when I am out shopping. However, it has some downsides. My last girlfriend did not like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that is why we broke up. It was hard, but you have to make sacrifices in any sport; you need to be serious and professional. It does not bother me too much. I am happy to focus on my game now and will catch up on other things in life after I retire, which comes early in this sport.

Young Shoppers**
Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very difficult for some parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the latest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and if I give in to their requests, I feel guilty about buying unhealthy food. I hate saying no all the time, and I get stressed before we even leave home. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry that they are missing out on learning how to make choices. I feel stuck."
Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they go shopping. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising aimed at children, mostly on television. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are a big part of this advertising. Children often do not understand why their parents say no to certain things, especially when they see attractive ads for sugary foods. 
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertising and often disappoint their children."
The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb points out, "The goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy products. Even if they cannot say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."
Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she talks to her children about food and advertisements. She feels that her son is critical of ads now, and they have less conflict in the supermarket because he does not ask for things she does not want to buy.
Parents also admit they are not always consistent with their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We refuse to buy sweets for our son because they are bad for him, but we buy double cream and chocolate for ourselves. It is nice to buy good things, and it is normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on my mood. If I feel good, I am more likely to say yes. It is hard to be consistent."
Supermarkets could help reduce the conflict between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Even if parents spend less money without their children, the idea of shopping without their kids’ demands might attract more customers.

**Five-Star Luxury and Modern Technology**
The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It was created by changing four large old houses into a hotel. This took a lot of research and nearly two years of work. The hotel has the latest technology to help both the staff and the guests.
Peter MacCann, the General Manager, wants his staff to know the guests' names. For more details about what guests like, he uses the hotel’s computer system. This system helps the hotel give special service to returning guests. It cost £250,000 to set up, but MacCann believes it will be worth it over time. He is happy with how well it works and the services it provides. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them when they come back.
Many hotel guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a high-tech system to control this. Guests can change the temperature in their rooms by three degrees around the normal 18°C. The front desk can also adjust the temperature anywhere from 14°C to 25°C.
Business guests will find the technology in their rooms very useful. MacCann thinks that about 65% of the hotel’s business will come from this group. To meet their needs, the hotel has put a business center in each room. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that can also copy and print, and a video-conferencing system.
Technology changes quickly, so the hotel has prepared for future improvements. They have added extra cables for new technology. The televisions are rented, so they can be replaced with newer models when needed. DVD recorders can also be updated.
Even with all this technology, MacCann wants guests to feel comfortable. The hotel has 145 large and well-furnished bedrooms that are welcoming. There is also a swimming pool, a gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.
The food at the hotel is very important. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. He has designed a new kitchen and improved the restaurant. The hotel also has better parking than before. This partnership is good for both the chef and the hotel. With great technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be successful.

**Where I Get My Energy**
Emma Marsden asked six women who live life fully to share how they find their energy.
A. **Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:** "I get my energy from excitement. I need to do things that challenge me. When I learn something new, I feel very energized. I also love rhythm; right now, I am learning flamenco dancing. Dance is amazing and gives me energy. If I am bored, I feel tired and think life is not worth it. Doing something meaningful, even in a small way, gives me energy."
B. **Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:** "I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it all. I love being at work; it is not a burden. If you enjoy what you do, you don’t feel sad, even if you are tired. I need enough sleep, and when I get it, I feel great. When I only sleep six hours, I feel a bit weak. I know exercise gives me energy, but sometimes it is hard to find the energy to do it! I go to a yoga class once a week and try to exercise at home. After I exercise, I feel much better. I often feel low in the afternoon, so I think it’s good to eat something then."
C. **Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey:** "I don’t eat healthy food for energy; I think my energy comes from being enthusiastic and positive. I dislike negative people. I believe we should enjoy our lives and make the most of every moment. Enjoyment is important. I love my job, and the last two years have been very exciting. I work with many lively young people, which energizes me. I enjoy taking photos, even if I’m not sure I’m good at it. I also write words for fun, which helps me relax when I travel a lot."
D. **Floella Benjamin, Author and Children's TV Presenter:** "My energy comes from doing things I love. I believe in what I do, both at work and at home with my family. Being positive helps me. I love working with kids because they are full of energy. Energy is like a natural feeling that comes from talking to others. Just smile at someone and see how good it feels when they smile back. I try to eat healthy and don’t smoke or drink, but I don’t have a strict exercise plan. I get my energy from playing with kids."
E. **Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright:** "What I love most is creating a garden from a wasteland. I once turned a concrete area into a beautiful garden. It was better than any workout. Knowing that someone wants to read my writing also gives me energy. I enjoy sneaking into a farmer's land or a forest. If I get caught, I say, 'Oh, what a lovely place! I didn’t know it was private.' I like this because it feels playful."
F. **Katherine Monblot, Therapist:** "I believe you need to care about what you do in life. I like to take risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things I don’t want to do makes me tired. I used to be part of many committees, but I didn’t like how they took my time. You only have a certain amount of energy, so use it for what matters most to you."

**ICE SKATING**
Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until iron skates were made in Scandinavia around 200 AD. For the rich people in Scandinavia, skating was an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was seen as stylish, but everything changed at the 1924 Winter Olympics when 11-year-old Sonja Henie showed a more athletic way of skating. This made skating very popular.
Today, skating combines art and sports. It is both beautiful and physically challenging. For beginners, balance and control are very important. You can only go faster when you become better at skating. The way you position your body helps with balance. Your legs should be slightly bent, and your knees should be relaxed. This helps keep your body weight centered and leans you slightly forward.
Relaxation is very important in skating. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. When you push forward with one foot, make a small movement with the other foot. It’s not too hard! If you keep practicing, you can slowly make bigger movements as you get better.
Learning how to fall is one of the first things a skater should know. Even professional skaters fall sometimes. To fall safely, you should stay relaxed. This helps reduce the impact when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, and then stand up.
Once you feel confident on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance skating, speed skating, and skating in pairs. It is best to start with figure skating and then learn basic freestyle. Most ice rinks have teachers who can help you learn the basic moves, and soon you will be able to do turns, jumps, and spins.
If you watch good skaters, you will see how relaxed they are and how easily they move. To skate well, you should practice exercises regularly. It can be dangerous to skate if your body is stiff, so warm-up exercises are important. These should include stretches for your legs, back, and shoulders, especially for your ankles and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to avoid stiffness.
Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also makes your heart and lungs stronger and helps your body become healthier. When combined with swimming or jogging, skating is a great way to stay fit.

**Trills and Bills**
If you want to see something that makes people cry happy tears, watch a talented child win a medal. Julia Gregson talked to three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges of their lives.
A. **Annika Reeder**, 15, won a gold medal for gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "Right now, the training is very hard. I don’t have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I take it one day at a time. When I feel really tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can’t take too many days off because it makes your body stiff."
B. **Annika's mother** says, "From a young age, Annika showed great talent. I have seen some parents push their children, but that doesn’t work. To perform at Annika's level takes a lot of time and energy, and you have to want to do it. People often say we, as parents, have given up a lot, but they don’t see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who hid behind me, but now she has met people from all over the world and gained confidence."
C. **Sarah Stokes** started show-jumping at age 10 and has won the British National Championship. "It’s great that my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. The shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it; I love show-jumping because it is exciting and fun. Even if my parents weren’t there, I would still do it because I am determined. I’m happy when they are proud of me, but I do it for myself. This year, I want to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."
D. **Sarah's mother** says, "From the moment Sarah sat on a horse at age 1, I knew she had a passion. When she was 5, she would wake up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, we travel all over England. To save money, we sleep in the horse box. Sarah is very organized. She is always happy on a horse and knows what to do. Watching your child succeed at something they love is amazing."
E. **Jane McShane**, 10, is the Under-14 Chess Champion in Britain. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it’s fun. When I play, I don’t focus as much as I should. I just look around and don’t think too much. I’m not worried about being proud; I don’t talk about my success at school because I don’t like to feel embarrassed."
F. **Jane's mother** says, "Jane played her first game when she was 5. My father said, 'Let’s see if she likes it.' He tried to teach me when I was young, but I was bored. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she had memorized all the moves, and by age 6, she was beating adults. I am happy when she wins, but if she wanted to stop playing tomorrow, I would support her. I don’t want to hold her back because she is so talented. If she has this gift, I want her to reach her full potential."

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. The teacher joked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain.
Every ten years, the average height of people in Europe increases by one centimeter. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are going back to how our ancestors were. We are losing the effects of many years of poor diet, which is making a big difference. Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, says, "We are becoming like Cro-Magnons again, the people who lived on Earth 40,000 years ago."
For most of human history, our ancestors ate a variety of foods. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming started, and this changed everything. Many green areas of the planet became farms, and now just three plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories people eat today. This poor diet has harmed human health. 
In a study in Ohio, scientists found that when they started to grow corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, which was thought to be good, actually caused health problems. However, farming spread because one piece of land could feed ten times more people than hunting and gathering. 
Today, many people are still poorly nourished, but some wealthier countries are starting to eat better again. In the US, the average man is now 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a good trend, but it has its own problems. Even though people are getting taller, beds have not changed in length since 1860. Also, there seems to be less legroom in planes and trains, and clothing companies have to change their products often.
The question is: how tall can we get? We cannot keep growing forever. Some scientists think we might reach a height of 193 cm this century. However, there is a note of caution. While people may be getting taller because of better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. 
During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were a bit rounder and taller to keep warm. Now that the climate is warmer, we seem to be getting thinner and shorter, even when we eat well. As the planet continues to warm, we might get even smaller. In other words, the growth of humans could be affected by global warming.

Studio Audiences**
What is it like to be in the audience when a television show is being made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of television, but many people do not understand them. When we watch game shows, we often wonder, "Who are these people?"
Some people think that studio audiences are not very important. I have heard that even people who work in television do not respect them. Some say they treat studio audiences "like cattle." I used to think that studio audiences were made up of silly people who wanted to be on TV for a moment. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from different backgrounds, jobs, and income levels. Television shows try to attract different types of people for different programs.
Many people who watch TV at home do not understand why anyone would want to be in a studio audience. Why would someone apply for tickets, travel far, and sit for hours in a studio just to watch what they can see at home? One reason is that people hope to be on TV for a moment. I did not believe this until I spoke to Angela. She said, "I came for a chance to be on television." Another reason is that people are curious to see how a show is made. But the most common reason I heard was, "A friend gave me a ticket."
Most of us have never been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it is like. You sit close to strangers while someone shows cards that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you clap or laugh when told. This is true for some shows, but not all. One studio manager said, "We believe a show should be good enough not to need these signs."
Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting." Charlotte liked feeling involved with live television. She said, "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him at home, you miss a lot." What I missed was seeing the live actors. From my seat, I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were so far away that I ended up watching the show on a monitor.
Going to a studio may not be the best way to watch television, but that is not what matters. For most people in the audience, it was just fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Favourite Places**
**Bruce**  
I don’t like wild landscapes. I prefer places with people. When I travel, I like beautiful villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham in its lovely valley. Cycling helped me relax from school. I enjoyed exploring the hills, valleys, and old villages. Coming from Scotland, I found the landscape familiar but also different. I still visit there today. I used to write about my adventures in my diary. This was my first try at travel writing, which later became my career.
**Sophia**  
There is a small train that goes from Hythe to Dungeness, run by volunteers. I always travel first class because it doesn’t cost much more than the regular ticket. The views are not amazing. The train goes across Romney Marsh with its sheep and next to a canal. But there is one part of the journey I always look forward to - when the train goes through back gardens. For a few moments, we see people doing everyday things, like making tea or folding a chair. I see myself in their eyes, a woman in a small train, looking into their homes. I like the simple landscape of fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. It makes me look more closely for something special.
**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a quiet and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and have many rocks, so there are not many people here. A few brave surfers come, but most visitors just enjoy the beauty of the sea. This coast faces the Atlantic and is known for shipwrecks. There are walking paths along the coast that you can combine with trips into beautiful valleys full of oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in a simple self-catering place with a family in the village of Southole.
**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland that is great for hiking. There are not many people living there or visiting. It is a quiet and remote area, and I like the feeling of space. I found this place by chance when I was a student, and I visit every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It has not changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits more special. I feel sad that he is growing up in a city.
**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. I wanted peace and to reconnect with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka, but when I was twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. There was a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you would never return. That place was Glenthorne. It is my dream place. It is a magical, quiet, romantic house. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**
We are a family that loves animals. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work to tell me she had found a beautiful pine snake. She asked, "Can we keep him?" I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We had a special tank ready for animals like this, so we could look at it and learn more from our natural history book.
I got home late and quickly started boiling some water when I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I ran to their bedroom. The problem was with Domino, our cat, and Bianca, the white mouse I had received as a Mother's Day gift. Domino was running around with the mouse in his mouth, trying to find a way out. I jumped into the room but tripped and fell on the floor. 
While I was thinking about how to stop Domino, I noticed the snake. It was escaping from the table and slithering all over the floor. The snake and I were in the middle of a chaotic scene with the cat, mouse, and kids all jumping around and screaming. The dog was barking loudly, and the pot in the kitchen boiled over. I quickly turned off the gas and went back to help.
I managed to grab Domino by the tail and saved the small, wet mouse from his mouth. This same mouse was caught by Domino three more times in its life but lived until it was old.
Feeling confident after saving the mouse, I looked at the snake. It seemed strong and calm. I sat on the floor, trying to stay still. Slowly, the snake relaxed and rested its head on its body. I carefully lifted the snake and walked to the end of the garden. I wanted to let it go near a tree.
When I finally let go of the snake's head, I was scared it would bite me. Instead, it slid over my shoulders like a colorful scarf. We stood there in the evening light, with my four children, me, and the snake. My oldest son, DJ, broke the silence and said, "Mum, you are warm, and the shed is not."
I asked the children to help me encourage the snake to move. Slowly, it started to go up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last part of its tail vanished, my three-year-old son Clay sighed and said, "Wow, that was one big snake!"

'Write to Me!'**
In our fast world with phones and computers, writing letters is becoming less common. However, I believe that receiving a letter is special and cannot be replaced by other ways of communicating. There is excitement when a letter arrives, joy in seeing who it is from, and happiness in reading what it says.
I have been writing letters for a long time. It started with little notes to my mother. She always made me write thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn’t matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I wrote to my parents every week, and they wrote back. Sometimes my father wrote long, funny letters, which I loved. Most of the letters were about everyday life with my parents and their friends. We also talked on the phone, but I remember the letters more.
I also received letters from my boyfriends. Many of them had to work or study far away, so we kept in touch by writing. Writing letters helped our relationships because I could express my feelings better in writing than in speaking. I enjoy letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but it’s even better to get a lot of news at once! I love receiving letters from friends in other countries, like Mangala in Sri Lanka, a penfriend in Australia, and another in Vancouver. I also have a friend in France. We started talking in a restaurant while on holiday, and I asked for her address. If she hadn’t replied, we would have missed out on a great friendship. Now, we write to each other regularly. I can practice my French with her, and we have visited each other’s homes.
My best letter-writing experience was this summer when my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. People were surprised that our friendship lasted so long, and the local newspaper even wrote about it. I am happy that my children are also writing letters. Like my mother, I make them write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did for my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, set up by my penfriend. I encourage everyone not to let letter writing become a lost skill.

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art**
Many ancient pictures carved into the rocks at a famous tourist site in France are being slowly destroyed. Scientists are worried that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged so quickly that they may not last for future generations. The mountain is thought to have been a place for prayer and worship, and it has drawings that are about 4,000 years old. These drawings show cows with horns, fields, and different gods and goddesses. 
As more people visit the site, the pictures are being ruined by careless graffiti. Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think that because the pictures have been there for so long, they will always be there. But if the damage continues like this, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, which wears away the rock and makes the artwork less clear. Some visitors even take pieces of the rock home as souvenirs. He also mentions that when people cannot take a good photograph, they rub the drawings to make them look clearer. 
Other researchers have noticed that some people come with long sticks to scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks. Experts disagree on how to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, the director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, believes the best way to save the site is to make the whole mountain a "no-go" area, allowing the public to visit only on guided tours. He says that if this does not happen, the site will be completely destroyed, and important research will be lost. 
Clottes disagrees with this idea. He says, "Henry de Lumley's plan is very strict, and while it may work, it will also upset the local people." He reminds us that the site was declared a historic monument by the Ministry of Culture, and we must do everything we can to protect it. 
David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He says, "Henry de Lumley's idea is not the best. Our department believes that people should be able to see the site, but it is hard to stop visitors from causing damage because the area is so large. I wish everyone could visit, but we do not have enough money to hire enough guards. We may need to think about charging a fee since there is no government funding." 
In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who has also studied the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to reach, the damage will increase quickly. She believes the only solution is to close off parts of the area and provide guides. "We cannot say we cannot do anything because there is no money," she says. "That is not good enough. Money must be found because the Ministry of Culture has classified this area as a historic site. If we do not take action, we will be responsible for losing the drawings for future generations."

Young Shoppers**
Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very difficult for some parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the latest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and if I give in to their requests, I feel guilty about buying unhealthy food. I hate saying no all the time, and I get stressed before we even leave home. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry that they are missing out on learning how to make choices. I feel stuck."
Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they go shopping. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising aimed at children, mostly on television. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are a big part of this advertising. Children often do not understand why their parents say no to certain things, especially when they see attractive ads on TV.
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertising and often disappoint their children."
The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb points out, "The goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy products. Even if they cannot say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."
Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she talks to her children about food and advertisements. She feels that her son is now critical of ads, and they have less conflict in the supermarket because he does not ask for things she does not want to buy.
Parents also admit they are not always consistent with their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We refuse to buy sweets for our son because they are bad for him, but we buy cream and chocolate for ourselves. It is nice to buy good things, and it is normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on my mood. If I feel good, I am more likely to say yes. It is hard to be consistent."
Supermarkets could help reduce the conflict between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Even if parents spend less money without their children, the idea of shopping without their kids’ demands might attract more customers.

Climbing Walls**
In the past, climbers went to the mountains to climb. Now, people can climb in many places, both inside and outside. A crowd watches as the French climber Francois Lombard hangs upside down by two fingers on a climbing wall. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at the National Indoor Arena in Birmingham. This arena is better known for the TV show Gladiators, but both events have one thing in common - The Wall. New technology has made these events possible.
Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were good climbing spots. In winter, they had to deal with cold weather, go for walks, or climb on snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing became more popular, it was important for climbers to stay fit. Since they could not use cliffs for much of the year, they started to climb on brick edges or stone buildings. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid boredom.
Soon, many sports centers built climbing walls using special bricks. One of the first climbing walls was made by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, in a corridor at Leeds University in the mid-1960s. He created a wall with natural rock set in concrete. Many climbing walls like this were built in sports halls in the 1970s, but they had some problems. These walls were only straight up and down, while real cliffs have different shapes like overhangs and slanted rocks. Once the walls were built, they could not be changed, and climbers would get bored with the same holds.
In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny created a new material that could be shaped like the rocks on cliffs. These shapes could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted something new. French companies also started to make climbing walls with steel frames. Steel was lighter than concrete, so it was easier to build overhanging walls. This new system allowed climbers to have many different holds to use.

'So You Want to Be an Actor'**
Do you want to be an actor? If you tell someone about your dream to be an actor, they will probably say it is a risky choice. Acting is indeed a risky career. There are many actors, but not enough jobs for all of them. When you decide to become an actor, some friends may think you are making a bad choice, while others may support you. Everyone will give you different advice. 
Choosing to be an actor is a personal decision, and you are responsible for your own success. There are no easy ways to become an actor. You do not have to take written tests, and there is no guarantee that you will get a job after your training. Success depends on both luck and talent. However, there is always a need for new actors, and acting can be exciting and rewarding.
Many people want to know what talent is. I think talent is a mix of natural skill and imagination. Imagination is hard to measure. It also depends on a person's courage and belief in their work. 
Why do people want to act? It can be hard to explain. In theater, the important moment is when the actor connects with the audience. This connection is what motivates actors to perform. When you ask successful actors how they achieved their success, they often do not have a clear answer. They know some things about their skills and techniques, but they do not take their success for granted. They understand that their success can change quickly.
Disappointment is a big challenge for actors. Last month, you might have been without work, doing other jobs like selling clothes or waiting tables. Then, you might get a chance to audition for a role. Even if you really want the job, you might not get it. Because of this, actors often avoid talking about their chances of getting a role. They find ways to cope with the stress of competition and the fear of rejection. No one likes to be rejected. 
From the moment you start auditioning, you are saying that you are ready and hopefully talented enough for the job. In many ways, your success depends on how much you care about acting. If you do not care, others may not care about you either.

**Food for Everyone**
We are happy to share our special selection of the best cookbooks available. 
A. When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, they often think of Delia Smith. Her recipes come from many places around the world, and she loves exciting food. She also understands what the average cook can do in a normal kitchen. The book that made her famous is "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course." This book is now a key reference for modern cooks. It gives simple but expert advice on basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of great recipes that are not boring. The book has been updated and is still the best choice if you could only have one cookbook.
B. Raymond Blanc became a well-known chef in just 15 years. He is the owner of a famous French restaurant in Britain. To go with his first TV series, "Blanc Mange," he has written a book with the same name. Raymond wants to help everyone become better cooks by showing how and why certain ingredients work together. He believes that good cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. The book has over 80 amazing recipes that show this. It is a practical book that explains why some dishes can go wrong and includes some basic food science. Raymond loves to cook for others, and this book shows that he is very good at it.
C. Le Cordon Bleu is a name that represents the best in French cooking. For 100 years, expert chefs at this famous cooking school have trained students to be great cooks. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, they have published a new book called "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook," which has 100 of the school's best recipes. The recipes are all classic but still feel fresh. While Le Cordon Bleu has always supported traditional French cooking, it has also changed to use less rich and creamy sauces to make healthier dishes. The book starts with basic kitchen skills and then includes Appetisers, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe has step-by-step pictures and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from Cordon Bleu schools around the world have chosen their famous recipes and shared their secrets.
D. Fast food? No way! Many people think that good food takes a long time to cook. But Nigel Slater, the food editor of The Observer, disagrees. His new book, "The 30-Minute Cook," shows that fast food can be good. Nigel believes that it is possible to make something tasty in the time it takes to get a pizza delivered. He has already written two successful books to prove this. In this new book, you will find many delicious recipes, and each one can be ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel writes in a fun and enjoyable way, sharing more than 200 recipes from around the world. Just because he likes fast food doesn’t mean he doesn’t appreciate good food. If you think fast food can’t be great, try his recipes—they are simply delicious!

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. The teacher joked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. 
Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by one centimeter. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are returning to how we were as cavemen. We are starting to lose the effects of many years of poor diet. Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, says, "We are beginning to reach our true potential. We are becoming like Cro-Magnons, the people who lived on Earth 40,000 years ago."
For most of human history, our ancestors ate a variety of foods. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming began, which changed everything. Farmers took over many green areas, and now just three plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories people eat today. This poor diet has harmed human health. 
In Ohio, scientists found that when they started to grow corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, which was thought to be good, actually caused health problems. However, farming spread because one piece of land could feed ten times more people than hunting could. 
Today, many people are still poorly nourished, but some wealthier countries are starting to eat better again. In the US, the average man is now 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a good trend, but it has its problems. Beds have not gotten longer since 1860, and there seems to be less legroom in planes and trains. Clothes manufacturers have to change their products often. 
The question is: how tall can we get? We cannot keep growing forever. Some scientists think we might reach a height of 193 cm this century. However, they also say that while individuals may be getting taller because of better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. 
During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller to keep warm. Now that the climate is warmer, we seem to be getting thinner and shorter, even when we eat well. As the planet continues to warm, we might shrink even more. In other words, our growth could be affected by global warming.

**A New Life**
**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He says, "After 14 years in the City, it became boring. No one was having fun anymore. I didn’t plan to leave yet, but I lost my job suddenly. I didn’t get a lot of money, but it was enough to start my farm. My big chance came when I met the head chef of a well-known hotel. By supplying them with meat, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat online. I’m happy to be out of the office, but I still work long hours, about 80 to 90 a week, and I’m still selling a product."
**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he is an artist. He started painting as a hobby and found it more exciting than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. A career counselor helped him, and he was surprised when Ron said he didn’t want to go back to his old job. Most people in their forties need to work for money. Ron and his wife moved to the north of England, where they didn’t know anyone. They left their friends behind, but they have kept in touch, and many friends visit them now.
**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat business in her London flat. She enjoyed being a lawyer and made good money, but the hours were long. She didn’t want to work more and more, so she left. Many people thought she would get bored, but she hasn’t. She says, "The secret is to have deadlines. In fashion, there is always a lot to do, so I have to keep a strict schedule. I feel happier now and less stressed. I do miss talking to colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am responsible for my work. If I do a bad job, it’s my fault. When I worked for a company, I cared, but now I care even more because my name is on everything."
**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started working in finance at 22, but he didn’t find it rewarding. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he decided to resign and travel for a year. During that year, he thought about what he wanted to do. He was interested in health, so he visited gyms and talked to the owners. He knew he needed qualifications to change careers, so he took courses in massage. Then he got a part-time job at the Life Centre. He has no regrets. He says, "I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my life. That is the best part."

A Winning Game**
Two brothers are finding that their childhood game is good for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, two bearded brothers in their forties, are sitting in their simple home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, and remembering their childhood. In front of them is a wooden board with round plastic pieces. They are playing the game of pichenotte, which they say is special. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, a grocer from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA and taught it to his family. Soon, every weekend and holiday, the family played the game and had a great time. Eventually, they moved to New Mexico, but they still played pichenotte with the board that Grandpa made from old wooden crates.
When visitors came over, they were often curious because the game was unknown in the southern USA. Three years ago, Dave noticed that the old pichenotte board was cracked and decided to make a new one. It turned out to be beautiful. A relative saw it and wanted one, then a friend wanted one too. To see how much interest there was, the brothers took one of Dave's new boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe. "People started to watch," says Dave, "and said, 'No way I'm playing that silly game.' But soon they sat down, and you couldn't get them up from the table!"
When people asked about the game's origins, Dave did some research. He found that the game probably started in India, where a similar game called 'carroms' is played. This game changed into 'squails' in Britain, and British people brought it to Canada. Pichenotte is the French-Canadian version that developed in Quebec. 
Pichenotte can be played by two to four people and is a game of skill. Each player has 12 pieces or 'pucks'. They flick the pucks across a wheel-like board using their fingers. Flicking a puck into a small hole is worth 20 points. There are three rings around the hole worth 15, 10, and 5 points. The game usually lasts about two minutes. 
When the brothers saw how popular the game was at the bar, they made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Many people came to buy them, and the game's popularity grew. Soon, championships started, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. As word spread, the boards sold quickly. The brothers decided to make pichenotte their full-time business. They set up a workshop in their garage and have made more than 450 boards. Each board is made of birchwood and mahogany, weighs 12kg, and is 1cm thick. Norm says, "They're very strong because they need to last a long time." 
Each board costs $595 and can be bought from the brothers' website. There are no professional pichenotte players or TV shows yet, but the brothers hope that one day their garage will be home to a luxury car instead of tools and wood. For now, they are happy to spend their free time playing the game they hope will make them successful.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**
When you first enter the Model Village, it is hard to believe that a few years ago this was just a piece of empty land, covered in weeds. For a long time, people thought it was useless. One man, with the help of his wife, worked very hard to change this land into the beautiful village you see today. 
Many tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into the lovely landscape you see now. Machines like bulldozers helped, but a lot of hard work was done by hand. After shaping the land, about 1,000 tons of topsoil were added to create the lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens. Hundreds of trees and bushes were also planted. These plants were chosen carefully because they needed to survive near the sea and withstand strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were brought from Canada and New Zealand.
The Model Village was created by Colin Sims, who made over 100 models by hand over nine years, starting in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, treated wood, and plastic to resist all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to learn how to use these materials, but soon he became an expert himself. 
You will notice that everything is built to the same scale, and even the smallest details are carefully made. This took a lot of patience and special building techniques. The Model Village is very popular and is known for its high quality and good maintenance. The methods used here have been used in other model villages in England and even taught in some college courses about modeling.
All the buildings in the village show traditional British styles and are not based on one specific place. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, which is a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower. You will also see a Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition to the village.
Please stay on the paths during your visit and do not touch the models; if you accidentally break something, it can take us a long time to fix it. You can take photos from the paths only. Dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead.
To make your visit more enjoyable, you will find buttons in front of some models. Press these buttons to see the models move. At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your comments. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us create a more interesting display. We also want to know if any models did not meet your expectations. We are always updating the models and need your feedback.
We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Don’t forget to tell your friends about us!

Every week, British tabloid newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy and break the rules set by newspaper editors. While some pop stars do pose for photographers sometimes, this is not common. More often, these pictures cause great harm to famous people when their private moments are shown on the front page. Very few of them ask for help from the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was created to handle these problems. These pictures rarely serve the public interest. For example, do private photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony help public health and safety? The actress has complained about such pictures before, and since she was in a hotel, where people expect privacy, she had a good reason to complain, but she did not take any action. It is a scandal that the PCC did not start an investigation. 
The PCC should also look into a recent story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action on this and other unfair stories? This seems like a good idea. It could lead to many decisions against newspapers. These decisions would be reported by other newspapers and shown on TV and radio. The public would not support these newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such stories. Photographers would also be affected, as they would not be able to hide and take pictures of celebrities anymore. 
If the PCC decided to act like a "police officer," there would be some problems. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it talk to the victim and encourage them to complain? And if the person still did not want to complain, should the PCC still investigate? Celebrities and royal family members might expect that any story about them would be looked into, and they might be upset if it is not. The job of the PCC is very big. How could it monitor all of the British press, including national and local newspapers and magazines? 
There is also the issue of embarrassment. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want the added embarrassment of an investigation? Most people probably just want to forget about it and continue with their lives. Some might have other reasons to stay quiet. They might have a worse story that they do not want to be made public if they complain. In this way, the PCC could also become a problem for them. 
One British comedian faced issues with the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He did not complain then, and he did not complain later when a photographer took pictures of him and his family during a holiday. He was afraid that the newspaper, News of the World, would publish the pictures again with a new story about his anger, saying they thought it was just a joke and that, as a comedian, he would have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People think they will become targets again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

Many college graduates get advice when they start their first job. This article talks about what to think about when looking for a second job. We are not talking about people who want a temporary job while they search for a permanent one, or those who leave a job they don’t like after a few weeks. Instead, we will focus on those of you who are ready to take a real step in your career. You have learned some skills and have an idea of what you want to do.
What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. You need to think about whether you want to specialize in a certain area, move up to a job with more responsibility, or change to a different field.
