Whatever you choose, it is important to pick your second job carefully. You should plan to stay in this job for two to three years. Future employers will look closely at this job when you apply for your next one. It should show that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, this job should help you grow, develop your skills, and give you more responsibilities.
If you want to travel, now is a good time to do it. You can work temporarily when you come back and then find your second job. Employers will be happy to see that you have traveled and are not likely to leave again soon.
Juliette Davidson spent her first year after leaving St. Aldate's College working for three lawyers. It was a good first job because they were supportive. She learned how to work in an office and improved her typing skills. However, there was no chance for promotion. One day, she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.
Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, "In two and a half years, I have become more skilled, and my job has really grown. From the start, my boss wanted to help me develop. My job title is the same, but my tasks have changed. I now do most of the correspondence and budgets, and I handle questions from company chairmen to people wanting to start their own business. Brenda includes me in all her work and also gives me specific projects and events to organize."

'What is the Secret of Confident People?'**
Confident people seem like they were born that way, but most say it is a skill they learned. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.
**A. Jenny**  
When I left school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. When I was about twenty-five, I helped at my daughter's school. I was nervous, but I did well. Someone suggested I take a university course. On my first day, I was very anxious, but my confidence grew over time. Working at the school changed my life and helped me in many ways.
**B. Michaela**  
Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive. I thought that was how confident people acted, but I learned that confidence comes from believing in yourself. If work gets too hard, I don’t feel guilty about leaving some tasks for the next day. When I face something difficult, I remind myself that I have nothing to lose. Fear can make you feel unconfident, so I talk to myself to calm my fears.
**C. Lisa**  
People think I am very confident, but I often feel scared inside. I learned to look confident because it is important in my job in TV. Interviewing people showed me that many of us feel tense in important situations. My mother gave me great advice when I was a teenager worrying about clothes: 'Who is looking at you? Everyone is too busy thinking about themselves.' I also believe that facing your fears helps you gain confidence. I was very nervous during my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt I could handle anything.
**D. Barbara**  
I feel confident because I enjoy my work, but I have built this confidence over time. If you keep working and learn from mistakes, you will feel more confident next time. I work hard and am liked at my restaurant, but not everyone likes me. I don’t let that bother me. You need to like yourself for who you are, not try to be what others want. My company offers training courses, which have helped my self-esteem. It is good to set small goals so you can see your progress instead of trying to do everything at once.
**E. Kim**  
After college, I worked as a secretary and often sat in meetings without speaking up. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my ideas. When I started working in politics, I was very nervous about speaking in public. I told myself, 'Don’t be silly. People do this every day, so you can too.' I also found it helpful to write down my thoughts, like having a comfort blanket. I believe everyone feels a bit nervous when speaking in public. The real secret to confidence is to keep telling yourself, 'Nothing is impossible.'

**Visit to Malaysia**
Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled when I gave him his torn kite. "You have to keep it," he said. "It's traditional - if the line breaks, finders keep it... and I have many more." He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All the kites were 120 cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and bamboo. We sat in the shade of the tall trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, and watched Malaysia's biggest kite festival.
In the center of the beach, there were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites. A line of nervous competitors held the lines of their kites and waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites flew into the air like rockets. More than 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts for five days every year. Each person entered four different kite designs, which were judged on decoration, stability in the air, and how well they flew. 
"Flying kites isn't so difficult," said Adnan, "but making them takes real skill. Visit me at home, and I'll show you how to do it." I received five invitations that day, and I decided to accept his. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large room. As night came, he asked me to come back the next day to help rebuild his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, through beautiful mountains with thick rainforests.
I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road ended at a river. A small boat was waiting to take people across. Nearby, I saw a sign that said: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." Before I started walking, it would have been good to know that most of the path was steep and slippery. When I reached the campsite, I met Baba, who took care of a kitchen and some bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about the insects under my thin mattress. 
At night, it was very dark, and I could hear many different sounds. A waterfall was loud nearby, and many creatures were moving around. In the morning, I saw a great view of five green mountain ranges. In the afternoon, it rained. First, there was wind, then lightning hit the trees. I got soaked. As I slid down the hill, I wondered how the big butterflies avoided the heavy rain. I also worried about my car getting washed away (it sometimes happens) and if I would drown if I opened my mouth. Luckily, my car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the hill.
In Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, everyone asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" But they were friendly. Kelantan is known for its kites, but I remember it more for the kindness of its people.

What Kind of Shopper Are You?**
We all go shopping, but we do it in different ways. Do you know what kind of shopper you are? Abby Edwards asked some people about their shopping habits.
A. **Melanie, 22, Dancer**  
"I love shopping! I can't spend enough money. When I have cash, I go shopping and feel happy. I can't walk past sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often go shopping together. We are both addicted to shopping!"
B. **Brenda, 40, Office Manager**  
"I don't like shopping much. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I take my son and daughter shopping for clothes, but I don't enjoy it because we all like different things. I don't spend money on myself often, so when I do, I feel guilty and tell my husband I spent less than I really did."
C. **Juliet, 28, Personnel Manager**  
"I only shop for what I need. I hate shopping and only go when I have to. When I do go, I know exactly what I want and I don’t want anything else. Shopping makes me tired, and I would rather be doing something else."
D. **Anita, 35, TV Producer**  
"I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don’t waste time and try to shop quickly. However, I have bought things I didn’t really need, so maybe I’m careful but sometimes make mistakes."
E. **Lizzie, 41, Secretary**  
"I really dislike shopping. I can never find what I want, and the shops are too noisy and messy. Luckily, I don’t have to shop for clothes often because I get most of my clothes for free. For food, I go to the supermarket once a week and do it quickly."
F. **Lisa, 22, Actress**  
"I think I’m a happy shopper. Sometimes I go shopping with my friends, and we often end up buying things. I don’t usually go with a specific item in mind, but if I see something I like, I buy it."
G. **Suki, 26, Art Gallery Assistant**  
"I’m a careful shopper. I enjoy shopping, but I don’t buy a lot. I usually know what I want and don’t spend too much. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but then I feel worse if I spend too much."
H. **Ann-Marie, 29, Nursery Worker**  
"I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it’s too busy. I’m a careful shopper. I have an idea of what I want and I look in different shops to find the best price, which takes a long time!"
I. **Linda, 32, Restaurant Manager**  
"I don’t like shopping much. Since I work in the city, shopping is not exciting for me anymore. When I have to shop, I don’t try things on because it’s too much trouble. The clothes I buy don’t always fit, but I don’t mind making mistakes."
